The voting place of Precinct No. 3 in Ward No. 2 shall be Thomas Harrison Middle School. 
(Code 1973,  1-12; Ord. of 9-11-01(1); Ord. of 1-13-09; Ord. of 5-10-11(1); Ord. of 9-8-15, eff. 12-31-15 ) 
Charter reference- Power of council as to wards and ward boundaries,  31. 
Sec. 1-1-13. - Central absentee voter election district. 
    There is hereby established, pursuant to section 24.2-712 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended, a central absentee voter election district (CAVED) for the City of Harrisonburg, Virginia. The location of the CAVED shall be a room in City Hall at 409 South Main Street, Harrisonburg, VA 22801. The CAVED is being established for presidential, gubernatorial, state general, local, primary and special elections. 
(Ord. of 3-10-92; Ord. of 1-27-98; Ord. of 7-27-04; Ord. of 8-31-15 ) 
Sec. 1-1-14. - Election of city council members at November general election. 
    Notwithstanding section 4 of the city charter and pursuant to section 24.2-222.1 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended, the members of city council shall be elected at the November general election, with their terms to commence on January 1 following the election for a four (4) year term. The first November general election shall be November 4, 2008 for the three (3) incumbent city council members whose terms expire on June 30, 2008. Those incumbent city council members shall continue in office until their successors are elected and commence their terms on January 1, 2009. The next November general election shall be November 2, 2010 for the two (2) incumbent city council members whose terms expire on June 30, 2010. Those incumbent city council members shall continue in office until their successors are elected and commence their terms on January 1, 2011. The municipal election for city council members shall be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday of November every second year thereafter. 
(Ord. of 11-14-06) 
Sec. 1-1-15. - Organizational meeting of city council. 
    Notwithstanding section 42 of the city charter and since the city council elections were changed from May to the November general election pursuant to section 24.2-222.1 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended, and section 1-1-14 of this Code, the members of city council which includes the newly elected members shall meet in the city council chambers at 10:00 a.m. on January 2 following the November regular municipal election, or on the following day if such day be on a Sunday or a legal holiday. After having first taken the oaths prescribed by law, all new city council members shall assume the duties of their office. Thereafter the council shall meet regularly at such times as may be prescribed by its rules, but not less frequently than once each month. Special meetings may be called and held at such time and is such manner as may be prescribed by its rules. All meetings of the city council shall be open to the public except when, by a recorded vote of two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of those members present, it is declared pursuant to an exception set forth in the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, that it is necessary to discuss public business in private, in which event the city council shall go into closed session. 
(Ord. of 1-8-08) 
Title 2 - THE CITY COUNCIL 
CHAPTER 1. - LEGISLATIVE ACTIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Powers vested in governing bodies, Va. Code,  15.1-7. 

ARTICLE A. - ORDINANCES 

Sec. 2-1-1. - Ordinances; style of ordinances and resolutions. 
    The style in which ordinances shall be enacted by the council shall be as follows: "Be it ordained by the council of the City of Harrisonburg:..."; and that in which resolutions shall be passed shall be as follows: "Be it resolved by the council of the City of Harrisonburg:.." 
(Code 1973,  2-2) 
Sec. 2-1-2. - Procedure for enacting general ordinances. 
    No general ordinance shall be adopted by the council, unless and until it shall have first been introduced at a meeting of the council, and thereafter at a subsequent meeting brought up, discussed and adopted in accordance with existing requirements respecting adoption of ordinances by the council. 
(Code 1973,  2-3) 
Sec. 2-1-3. - Amendment and repeal of ordinances. 
    No ordinance shall be amended or repealed except by an ordinance regularly introduced and adopted. 
(Code 1973,  2-4) 
Sec. 2-1-4. - Filling blanks involving money or time. 
    In filling blanks in ordinances or resolutions involving money or time, the question shall be put first upon the largest sum or longest time. 
(Code 1973,  2-5) 
Sec. 2-1-5. - When ordinances to take effect. 
    Every ordinance shall take effect from the date of its passage, unless otherwise provided. 
(Code 1973,  2-6) 
Secs. 2-1-6-2-1-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - FRANCHISES 

Sec. 2-1-11. - Franchises and sales, leases, etc., of public property; required vote of council. 
    No ordinance or resolution granting, leasing, selling or otherwise disposing of any public property or franchise shall be valid unless the same be passed by the council by a recorded affirmative vote of at least four (4) members. 
(Code 1973,  2-7) 
Sec. 2-1-12. - Election prerequisite to sale of certain municipal utilities. 
    The water, sewer and electric systems of the city, now owned or hereafter acquired, shall not be sold, even after such action of the council as is prescribed by section 2-1-11, until and except such sale shall have been approved by a majority of the qualified voters of the city, voting on the question at a special election ordered by the council, and held pursuant to the method provided by law; provided, that machinery, equipment and accessories owned by the city and now or formerly used in and about the operation of the water, sewer and electric systems, when no longer needed or used for the efficient operation of one (1) or more of such systems, or when replacement thereof is necessary or advisable, shall not be subject to the referendum hereinbefore in this section prescribed for the sale of such systems. 
(Code 1973,  2-8) 
CHAPTER 2. - MEETINGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Limitations on executive sessions, Va. Code,  2.1-340 et seq. (Virginia Freedom of Information Act). 

Sec. 2-2-1. - Members to attend meetings; effect of failure to attend three consecutive meetings. 
    All members of the council shall attend all meetings thereof. If any member fails, for any reason except sickness, to attend three (3) consecutive regular meetings of the council, his office may be declared vacant by the mayor and the council shall proceed to elect a successor for the unexpired portion of the term of office of the absent member. 
(Code 1973,  2-9) 
Sec. 2-2-2. - Disorderly behavior of council members; malfeasance in office. 
    The council may, by a majority vote of its whole number, punish one of its own members for disorderly behavior by a fine not exceeding fifty dollars ($50.00) and may, by a three-fifths ( 3/5 ) vote of its whole number, expel a member of its own body for malfeasance or misfeasance in office. Fines imposed under this section shall be collected in such manner as fines imposed by the district court. 
(Code 1973,  2-10) 
Sec. 2-2-3. - Departure from order of business. 
    There shall be no departure from the order of business as set out in section 2-3-23 except upon unanimous consent. 
(Code 1973,  2-11) 
Sec. 2-2-4. - Suspension of rules. 
    No rule of order of the council shall be suspended except by consent of at least three-fifths ( 3/5 ) of the whole council. Any such suspension of rules may be made upon a motion. 
(Code 1973,  2-12) 
Sec. 2-2-5. - Meetings; regular meetings. 
    The council shall hold its regular meeting at the council chamber located in the municipal building complex, or at such other place in the city as may be designated by the council, on the second and fourth Tuesdays of each month at 7:00 p.m., unless such day falls on a legal holiday or on a local, state or federal election day, in which case it shall be held on the next day following. 
(Code 1973,  2-13; Ord. of 7-11-06) 
Charter reference- Regular meetings of council,  42. 
Sec. 2-2-6. - Special meetings. 
    A special meeting of the council may be called at any time by the mayor. In case of his absence, inability or refusal, the council may be convened by the order of any two (2) members of the council and in such case the call shall be in writing and state the purpose for which the meeting is called. Special meetings may be held at any time without notice, provided all members of the council attend and unanimously consent to the transaction of all business transacted thereat. No business shall be transacted at a special meeting, except that for which it shall have been called, unless by unanimous consent of all the members of the council. Except in case of emergency no special meeting shall be held at any time other than 7:30 p.m. 
(Code 1973,  2-14) 
Charter reference- Special meetings of council,  42. 
Sec. 2-2-7. - Absence of quorum. 
    If a quorum fails to attend a meeting within twenty (20) minutes after the appointed time for such meeting, those present may adjourn to such time as they deem proper, after the names of those present shall have been entered on the journal. 
(Code 1973,  2-15) 
CHAPTER 3. - RULES AND PROCEDURE 

Sec. 2-3-1. - Robert's Rules of Order. 
    The proceedings of the council, except as otherwise provided in this chapter, shall be governed by Robert's Rules of Order, Jove Edition/September 1977. 
(Code 1973,  2-16; Ord. of 7-25-00; Ord. of 8-24-04) 
Sec. 2-3-2. - Enforcement of rules; preservation of decorum. 
    The mayor shall enforce the rules of the council and preserve order and decorum. 
(Code 1973,  2-17) 
Sec. 2-3-3. - Certain procedures concerning the development of the agenda for council meetings and the conduct of meetings, generally. 
(a)  Agenda development. 
(1)  The city manager shall determine what items are placed on the agenda for regular and special council meetings, except that any single council member may require that an item be placed on the agenda. Any member of the public who has had a request to have an item placed on the agenda denied by the city manager may have such item placed on the agenda if two (2) or more council members so request. 
(2)  All agenda items, with any supporting exhibits or attachments, must be submitted to the city clerk no later than 5:00 p.m. of the Tuesday before regular council meetings, and no later than noon of the third working day before any non-emergency special meeting. Agenda items for emergency meetings shall be submitted as soon as possible. 
(3)  Attachments or exhibits for agenda items submitted by council members that are not submitted by the deadline set forth in the preceding subsection shall not be discussed until all council members have had at least three (3) work days to review the material or all have consented to a sooner discussion of such late submittals. 
(4)  Agenda items shall be presented to council members under a cover sheet that includes, at a minimum, a summary statement of the subject and content of the agenda item, and an indication of the party requesting the item. The party requesting a discussion in closed session shall be noted on the agenda. 
(b)  Time limit. Unless approval is granted by the city manager prior to the meeting, which shall be granted sparingly, the presentation of any single agenda item shall be limited to fifteen (15) minutes, regardless of the number of presenters, not counting time taken by comments or questions from council members or the public, if permitted. The mayor, or another holding the gavel, may grant a short extension of time, on a case by case basis, to allow for the conclusion of a presentation. 
(c)  Public comment. No member of the public may speak to any agenda item except: 
(1)  When the item is set for public hearing or 
(2)  When a majority of the council or the presiding officer indicates a desire to hear from the person. Due consideration shall be given to hearing from possible opposing viewpoints before action is taken when no notice was given that an opportunity to speak would be allowed. 
(d)  Taking action. No action shall be taken on any matter not on the agenda without the council's unanimous consent. 
(e)  Closed sessions. 
(1)  No matter shall be placed on the agenda for closed session except by the city manager. 
(2)  Matters to be placed on the closed session agenda shall be identified and described as much as possible, with due consideration to confidentiality, on the regular agenda. Therefore, items for closed sessions shall meet the same deadline as other agenda items, except for issues emerging after the deadline and which must be presented to the council before the next regular meeting. The city manager shall inform council members of any closed session agenda item added after publishing the agenda by the most expedient manner available. 
(Ord. of 12-9-03; Ord. of 9-27-05) 
Sec. 2-3-4. - Memoranda regarding council administrative procedures. 
    At least once every two (2) years during the meeting at which newly elected members are inducted, as prescribed in section 42 of the Charter of the city, and more often as seen fit, the council shall review previously approved memoranda of council administrative procedures and shall reapprove such memoranda, with any amendments, deletions or additions agreed to by a majority of the council. 
(Ord. of 11-25-03) 
Sec. 2-3-5. - Members withdrawing without leave. 
    After a member of the council has at any meeting been recorded as present, he shall not, without permission of the council, absent himself from such meeting until its adjournment. 
(Code 1973,  2-20) 
Sec. 2-3-6. - Conduct in addressing council. 
(a)  Every member of the council shall confine himself to the question before the council and avoid personal, or indecorous language. No discussion of a sectarian or political nature shall be allowed. No member shall interrupt another while speaking, except to make a point of order, the point to be briefly stated to the presiding officer. 
(b)  No member shall, while the council is sitting, interrupt or hinder its business by standing, moving about, talking, expressing approval or disapproval of any of the proceedings, or by any conduct tending to disorder or confusion. 
(Code 1973,  2-21) 
Secs. 2-3-7-2-3-9. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Sections 2-3-7-2-3-9 were repealed by an ordinance adopted July 25, 2000. Said sections pertained to order of recognition by mayor, the number and length of speeches, and how called to order when councilmembers address the council and were derived from Code 1973,  2-22-2-24. 
Sec. 2-3-10. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted Dec. 9, 2003, repealed  2-3-10 in its entirety. Former  2-3-10 pertained to nonmembers addressing council and derived from Code 1973,  2-25. 
Sec. 2-3-11. - Communications to be in writing. 
    No communication, petition or request to the council shall be entertained, unless the same be in writing, which must be filed with the city manager. 
(Code 1973,  2-26) 
Secs. 2-3-12-2-3-18. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Sections 2-3-12-2-3-18 were repealed by an ordinance adopted July 25, 2000. These sections contained various provisions dealing with motions and previous questions and were derived from Code 1973,  2-27-2-33. 
Sec. 2-3-19. - Majority vote to govern unless otherwise provided. 
    In all matters pending before the council, a majority shall govern, except in cases where it is otherwise specially provided. 
(Code 1973,  2-34) 
Sec. 2-3-20. - Voting procedure; interested members not to vote. 
(a)  On the call of any member of the council, the vote on any question may be taken by ayes and noes, and recorded, provided the demand be made before other business has been taken up. 
(b)  A member who is present and fails to vote when the ayes and noes are taken shall be entered on the journal as present and not announcing his vote. 
(c)  No member who has an immediate, personal or pecuniary interest in the result of the question shall either vote or be counted upon it. 
(Code 1973,  2-35) 
Sec. 2-3-21. - Dissent or protest. 
    Any member of the council shall have the liberty to dissent from or protest against, any ordinance, resolution or order of the council and have the reason of his dissent entered upon the record. 
(Code 1973,  2-36) 
Sec. 2-3-22. - Calendar of unfinished business. 
    A calendar of all new, referred and deferred petitions and communications to the council shall be kept by the city clerk who shall deliver to the city manager seven (7) days before any regular council meeting seven (7) copies of such calendar. 
(Code 1973,  2-37) 
Sec. 2-3-23. - General order of business. 
    At every regular meeting of the council, the order of business shall be as follows: 
(1)  Roll call. 
(2)  Invocation. 
(3)  Pledge of allegiance. 
    The remaining order of business at every regular meeting of the council shall be set by the city manager, which order of business may change from meeting to meeting. Comment from the public, limited to five (5) minutes, on matters not on the regular agenda, shall be heard under Other Matters. 
(Code 1973,  2-38; Ord. of 3-9-93; Ord. of 7-12-94; Ord. of 10-25-94; Ord. of 2-10-04; Ord. of 8-8-06; Ord. of 1-10-17) 
Sec. 2-3-24. - Special order of business. 
    When any matter is made the special order for a future meeting, it shall at such meeting take priority over all other business, except the reading of the minutes of the previous meeting. 
(Code 1973,  2-39) 
Sec. 2-3-25. - Voting at elections. 
(a)  At all elections by the council the voting shall be viva voce and each member shall be entitled to one (1) vote. Once one (1) person shall be elected at a time, except with the consent of all members present. If, on any vote, no one receives a majority of all the votes, the name of the person receiving the smallest number of votes shall be dropped and shall not again be put in nomination until a vote intervenes. 
(b)  At each election the roll shall be called by the clerk in alphabetical order, and each member shall vote when his name is called, unless excused or disqualified. 
(Code 1973,  2-40) 
CHAPTER 4. - COUNCIL PAY 

Sec. 2-4-1. - Procedure for refusal or reduction of council pay, increases. 
(a)  Any city council member may refuse any pay or pay increase, in whole or in part, for any reason. 
(b)  When a council member decides to refuse pay or a pay increase, in whole or part, he shall notify the city manager of his decision in writing. The city manager may require such council member to sign additional documentation as may be deemed reasonably necessary by the city manager. 
(c)  The refusal of pay or pay increase, or part thereof, shall remain in effect from the time of its submission until its revocation in writing by the council member. Revocations will be made available as public information. 
(Ord. of 11-25-03) 
Title 3 - CITY ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Duties, compensation of city manager, Va. Code,  15.1-795; city manager plan, Va. Code, Title 15, Ch. 19, Art. 4. 

CHAPTER 1. - CITY MANAGER 

Sec. 3-1-1. - Duties generally. 
    The city manager shall perform all the duties provided for in the Charter, the ordinances of the city and by general law. 
Charter reference- Provisions relative to city manager,  37, 38 and  46-49. 
Sec. 3-1-2. - Authority to execute contracts and agreements. 
    The city manager shall have authority to execute all contracts and agreements on behalf of the city except as otherwise directed by the council in specific instances. 
(Code 1973,  2-51) 
Sec. 3-1-3. - Deputy city manager. 
(a)  The city manager shall appoint a deputy city manager, whose term of office shall be at the pleasure of the city manager. 
(b)  The deputy city manager shall perform the duties of the city manager in his absence and all other duties as may be assigned to him by the city manager. During the tenure of the deputy city manager, he shall reside within the city. 
(Code 1973,  2-52; Ord. of 10-21-15(2)) 
Sec. 3-1-4. - Authority of city manager to accept interests in real estate on behalf of city. 
    Pursuant to section 15.2-1803, Code of Virginia (1950), as amended, any deed purporting to convey real estate, or an interest in real estate, to the City of Harrisonburg, shall be valid only when it is accepted on behalf of the city by the mayor or city manager. Acceptance shall appear on the face of such deed or on a separately recorded instrument. 
(Ord. of 10-26-00) 
Cross reference- Authority of mayor to accept interests in real estate on behalf of city,  3-7-1. 
Sec. 3-1-5. - Authority of city manager to consent to vacations of interest in streets, alleys, easements, etc. on behalf of city. 
    Pursuant to sections 15.2-2270 and 15.2-2271 of the Code of Virginia (1950), as amended, the city manager is hereby appointed the city's authorized agent to consent to vacations of any interest in streets, alleys, easements for public rights of passage, easements for drainage, and easements for a public utility granted to the city as a condition of the approval of a site plan or subdivision. The city manager shall consent to such vacation only after considering the recommendation of city staff. Nothing herein shall preclude the city manager from presenting a proposed vacation to city council should the city manager, in his discretion, determine that the decision should be made by the council. An owner of real estate that adjoins, or over which runs, an interest in real estate proposed for vacation, who disagrees with the decision made by the city manager, may ask for the council to consider the matter, so long as such owner files a request with the city manager's office within one calendar month of the decision of the city manager, that the matter be placed on the agenda for a regularly scheduled council meeting. 
(Ord. of 6-26-01(1)) 
CHAPTER 2. - CITY ATTORNEY 

Sec. 3-2-1. - Election by council; term of office. 
    The city council shall elect a city attorney who shall hold office for a term of two (2) years. Said election shall be made and said term shall begin at the organizational meeting of the city council held in accordance with section 1-1-15 of this Code following each regular municipal election. 
(Code 1973,  2-53; Ord. of 1-22-85; Ord. of 1-8-08) 
Sec. 3-2-2. - Duties generally. 
    The city attorney shall have the management, charge and control of all legal business of the city. He shall be the legal advisor of the council, or city officials in matters pertaining to their respective offices. He shall attend all meetings of the council, and furnish written or oral legal opinions upon any subject pertaining to the affairs of the city, and requested by the mayor or council or city manager. He shall draft all ordinances, bonds or other legal papers pertaining to the city's affairs. It shall be his duty to commence and prosecute all actions and suits brought by the city, before any tribunal in the state, whether in law or in equity and to appear and defend the rights of the city in any action, suit or prosecution. 
(Code 1973,  2-54) 
Sec. 3-2-3. - Compensation; allowed expenses. 
    The yearly salary of the city attorney shall be in such amount as may be fixed by the council and shall be payable monthly and shall be in full compensation for all services rendered the city. In addition to the yearly salary the city attorney shall be entitled to the same fringe benefits as all other city employees, which benefits include, but are not limited to, vacation, sick leave, health, dental and life insurance and participation in the state employees retirement system. Further, all professional dues of the city attorney, along with all professional development programs shall be paid for by the city. When the duties of the city attorney requires his presence out of the city, his reasonable expenses shall be payable in full in advance or reimbursed upon receipt of duly executed expense or petty cash vouchers, receipts or personal affidavits. 
(Ord. of 12-13-05) 
CHAPTER 3. - CITY CLERK 

Sec. 3-3-1. - Election by council; supervision by city manager and term of office. 
    The city council shall elect a city clerk, who shall work and be supervised by the city manager and shall hold office at the pleasure of the city manager. 
(Code 1973,  2-56; Ord. of 1-11-11(1)) 
Editor's note- Ord. of 1-1-11(1) amended  3-3-1 title to read as herein set out. Former  3-3-1 title pertained to election by council; term of office. 
Charter reference- Provisions re city clerk,  41. 
Sec. 3-3-2. - Inspection of records, etc. 
    All books, records and papers in the city clerk's custody shall be open to the inspection of the members of the city council, the city attorney or any other officer of the city, who in the discharge of his duties, may have occasion to examine the same. 
(Code 1973,  2-57) 
Sec. 3-3-3. - Attendance at council meetings. 
    The city clerk shall attend all meetings of the council. 
(Code 1973,  2-58) 
Sec. 3-3-4. - Minute book of council. 
    Promptly after each meeting of the council, the city clerk shall record in the minute book of the council, a brief, concise and accurate statement of all material proceedings had at such meeting, including reference to all ordinances introduced, enacted, amended or repealed, and the amounts and purpose of all appropriations made. The minute book shall be properly indexed and remain in the custody of the city clerk and be subject to the inspection at any time by any city official or citizen. 
(Code 1973,  2-59) 
Sec. 3-3-5. - Ordinance book. 
    There shall be an ordinance book in which the city clerk shall properly record and index all ordinances adopted by the council. It shall be the duty of the city clerk when any ordinance is amended or repealed by a subsequent ordinance, to note on the margin of the amended ordinance the fact of such amendment or repeal, and a reference to the subsequent ordinance effecting such amendment or repeal. 
(Code 1973,  2-60) 
Cross reference- Ordinances of council, Title 2, Ch. 1. 
Sec. 3-3-6. - Furnishing copies of records, ordinances, etc. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk to have transcribed or copied and furnished any city official, bureau, department or agency copies of any records, communications, ordinances, extracts from the minutes of the council or any other records which the clerk may have on file in the clerk's office upon request. 
Sec. 3-3-7. - Filing and preservation of communications, reports, etc. 
    The city clerk shall file and preserve all written communications and reports directed to the council, all written opinions furnished by the city attorney to the council or its committees, and such other papers and books as may be deposited with the clerk or such other matters referred to the clerk by the council for filing. 
(Code 1973,  2-62) 
Sec. 3-3-8. - Supervision of printing of reports and ordinances. 
    The city clerk shall supervise the printing of all official reports and ordinances ordered by the council to be printed. 
(Code 1973,  2-63) 
Sec. 3-3-9. - Custodian of city seal. 
    The city clerk shall be the custodian of the city seal. 
(Code 1973,  2-64) 
Sec. 3-3-10. - Additional duties. 
    The city clerk shall perform generally all duties properly appertaining to the office of the city clerk and all duties required or assigned by the city manager. 
(Code 1973,  2-65; Ord. of 1-11-11(2)) 
CHAPTER 4. - CITY DEPARTMENTS AND OFFICES 

Sec. 3-4-1. - Creation of departments and offices. 
    The following departments and offices of the city are hereby created: 
(1)  Office of city manager; 
(2)  Office of the commissioner of revenue; 
(3)  Office of city treasurer; 
(4)  Department of finance: 
a.  Finance; 
b.  Risk management; 
c.  Purchasing; 
(5)  Department of police; 
(6)  Department of fire;

(8)  Department of transportation: 
a.  Central garage; 
(9)  Department of public utilities: 
a.  Water; 
b.  Sewer; 
(10)  Department of community development: 
a.  Building code inspections;

(12)  Department of economic development: 
a.  Economic development;

(13)  Department of human resources; 
(14)  Department of information technology. 
(Ord. of 2-12-91; Ord. of 4-27-93; Ord. of 10-25-05) 
Sec. 3-4-2. - Directors of departments; appointment; duties. 
    Each department of the city shall have a director who shall be appointed and removed by the city manager provided by the city charter. The directors of departments, subject to the direction of the city manager, shall be responsible for the supervision and administration of the affairs of their respective department. 
Charter reference- Appointment and removal of department heads, city charter,  47(8). 
Sec. 3-4-3. - Organization and functions of departments. 
    The organization and functions of city departments shall be as prescribed by this Code or as otherwise provided by directive of the city manager. 
CHAPTER 5. - PERSONNEL 

Sec. 3-5-1. - Personnel classification system and uniform pay plan. 
    The Personnel Classification System and Uniform Pay Plan of the City of Harrisonburg, Virginia, dated 1991, based on surveys conducted by Yarger and Associates, Inc., conducted August, 1990 and December, 1990, and approved by the city council in regular session January 22, 1991, and as may hereafter be amended from time to time by the city council, is hereby recognized as the personnel classification system and uniform pay plan of the city. Such personnel system shall include the compensation plan, provisions for administration of the system, the salary schedule and class specifications for various classes of positions within the city. 
(Ord. of 2-12-91) 
Sec. 3-5-2. - Authority of department heads to employ and discharge employees; management of employees. 
(a)  The heads of all the departments and offices of the city shall have the authority to employ or discharge any of the employees working in their respective departments and offices, except the departments of public health and public schools. Such department and office heads shall immediately certify the change of personnel in their respective departments or offices to the city manager. 
(b)  All persons engaged by the city as employees in particular departments shall at all times be under the management and direction of the superintendent or head of such department. 
(Code 1973,  2-41) 
Charter reference- City officers and employees,  50-55. 
Sec. 3-5-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. of 3-25-08(1), repealed  3-5-3, which pertained to retirement age. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 3-5-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 3-5-4, setting out the city holiday, and derived from provisions presumably enacted during the original (1979) codification, was repealed by an ordinance adopted June 28, 1988. 
Sec. 3-5-5. - No work on Saturdays; exceptions. 
    Except the police and fire departments and such other employees as may affect the operation of the public utilities, city employees shall not be required to work on Saturdays. In the event any employee, not required by this section to work on Saturday, does so work, then they shall take an equal amount of time off the following week. However, this section shall have no application in case of emergency. 
(Code 1973,  2-44) 
Sec. 3-5-6. - Annual vacation (Reserved). 
Note- See  8.3 of personnel system rules as to vacation leave. 
Sec. 3-5-7. - Sick leave (Reserved). 
Note- See  8.4 of personnel system rules as to sick leave. 
Sec. 3-5-8. - Traveling expense accounts. 
    All traveling expense accounts submitted by any city official or employee to the office of the auditor for payment shall show the dates expenses were incurred or paid, points between which traveled, number of miles traveled, method of travel, hotel expenses, meals, incidental expenses, such as telegrams, telephone calls, etc., to be specified in each instance, and the concise statement of the purpose of or reason for such travel expense. 
Sec. 3-5-9. - Employees of constitutional officers. 
    It is acknowledged that the employees of the commissioner of the revenue and the treasurer are employees of these constitutional officers and are employees whose positions and base salaries are established by the state compensation board; however, state law authorizes the inclusion of such employees in a locality's personnel system and authorizes the local governing body to supplement the salaries of such employees. It is the policy of the City of Harrisonburg to provide for the inclusion of the employees of constitutional officers in the classification plan for service, the uniform pay plan of the city and further subject said employees to the city's policies as set forth in the personnel policy manual, upon agreement by the affected constitutional officer and the city council. The inclusion of such employees in the city plan shall not change the status of such employees as employees of a constitutional officer nor deprive the constitutional officer of control over the actions of his or her employees, but shall serve as the basis for supplementation of salaries, benefits and training as permitted by law. The inclusion of such employees in the classification and uniform pay plans, and the personnel policy manual shall not constitute inclusion in the city's grievance procedure unless expressly agreed to by the constitutional officer and the city council. 
(Ord. of 1-27-98) 
Sec. 3-5-10. - Inclusion of employees of constitutional officers in city plans and personnel policy manual. 
    Upon presentation by the constitutional officer of a written proposal for the inclusion of his or her employees in the city's classification plan for service, uniform pay plan and further subject to the city's personnel policy manual, council may, if it finds that the proposals are consistent with the criteria in the city's plans, and that inclusion is in the best interests of the city, approve the inclusion of that constitutional officer's employees in the city's plans and further subject to the city's personnel policy manual. The payment of salaries and wages for such employees shall be made from funds appropriated by the commonwealth for those positions and as may be supplemented from time to time with fiscal funds appropriated by city council. When approved by council, the inclusion of such employees with the city plans and subject to the city's personnel policies shall remain in effect until amended or discontinued by council, or until discontinued by the affected constitutional officer. 
(Ord. of 1-27-98) 
Sec. 3-5-11. - Criminal history background checks for new employees. 
    This section is enacted pursuant to Sections 19.2-389 and 15.2-1503.1 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended. In the interest of public welfare and safety it is necessary to determine whether the past criminal and/or child protective services conduct of each person seeking to be employed with the city is compatible with the nature of the person's employment. Further pursuant to 12 VAC 5-31-540, it is necessary for the city to have a record documenting the results of a criminal history background check on an individual accepting employment to provide emergency medical services or on other individuals to be employed with the city. 
(1)  Any applicant who accepts employment with the City of Harrisonburg as emergency medical services personnel, providing services to juveniles, the elderly or, as deemed necessary by the city manager or his designee in the interest of public welfare and safety, shall, as a condition precedent to employment, submit and provide required personal descriptive information for the purpose of all criminal history background checks. 
(2)  Upon receipt of the personal descriptive information provided by the applicant, the human resources department of the city will transmit it and any appropriate fees (unless a satisfactory billing arrangement has been made) to the city's designated background check agency for (i) a criminal history record information review and (ii) sex offender and crimes against minors registry searches which shall be reported to the human resources department, as further required by this ordinance. 
(3)  The city's designated background check agency will compare the applicant's personal descriptive information against its nationwide criminal file(s) and records. 
(4)  The results of the criminal history background check will disseminate the state and national results to the human resources department of the city. 
(5)  The applicant may request and receive a copy of the criminal history record information results from the human resources department of the city. Should the applicant seek to amend or correct the record(s) relating to the reported results, the applicant must contact the city's designated background check agency for records from other jurisdictions maintained in its file. 
(Ord. of 5-13-08; Ord. of 2-26-13) 
CHAPTER 6. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND AUTHORITIES 
ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 3-6-1. - Creation and composition; terms. 
(a)  The council shall create boards, commissions or councils which shall perform duties prescribed by the council, including, but not limited to, making studies, conducting research and investigations, holding hearings, and preparing recommendations as to needed ordinances and resolutions. 
(b)  The council shall provide for the make-up and composition of such boards, commissions or councils, the periods of existence, and for the compensation of such members and employees of same, in whole or in part. The council shall provide by ordinance for reimbursement of the actual and necessary expenses incurred by the members thereof in the performance of their official duties. 
(c)  The terms of office of members of all boards, commissions, councils and authorities now in existence or hereafter created shall be limited to two (2) successive terms. For the purposes of this section, if a vacancy occurs on any board, commission, council or authority and if one-half or more of the unexpired term remains to be served, then the serving of the unexpired term by the newly appointed member shall be considered the first full term of the newly appointed member. 
(Ord. of 6-28-88) 
Sec. 3-6-2. - Vacancy in office; removal. 
(a)  Any vacancy in office of any member of a board or commission shall be filled for the unexpired term in the manner prescribed for original appointment. 
(b)  Any member of a board or commission may be removed from office for cause by a majority vote of the council members present. 
Sec. 3-6-3. - Bylaws, rules, regulations, officers. 
    Each board and commission may establish such bylaws, rules and regulations and officers not inconsistent with the law or ordinance of the council, as it deems appropriate and necessary for the conduct of its affairs, copies of which shall be filed with the clerk of council. 
Secs. 3-6-4-3-6-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - SHENANDOAH VALLEY JOINT AIRPORT COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city and county to act jointly with regard to airports, Va. Code,  5.1-35 and 5.1-36. 

Sec. 3-6-11. - Establishment and designation; where powers, etc., exercised. 
    There is hereby established, in conjunction with the participating cities and counties, a joint airport commission, to be known as the Shenandoah Valley Joint Airport Commission, for the Counties of Augusta and Rockingham and the Cities of Harrisonburg, Staunton and Waynesboro, Virginia, and shall exercise its powers and functions therein. 
(Code 1973,  2-152) 
Sec. 3-6-12. - Composition; appointment, terms and removal of members. 
    The Shenandoah Valley Joint Airport Commission, hereinafter referred to as the "commission," shall consist of one (1) member from each of the participating counties and cities, appointed by the governing bodies thereof respectively for staggered terms of office now in effect. All appointments shall be for three (3) year terms, except appointments to fill vacancies which shall be for the unexpired terms. The governing body appointing any member may remove such member at any time and appoint his successor. 
Sec. 3-6-13. - Compensation of members. 
    All members of the commission shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1973,  2-154) 
Sec. 3-6-14. - Election of chairman, secretary and treasurer. 
    The commission shall have power to elect a chairman, a secretary and a treasurer. 
(Code 1973,  2-155) 
Sec. 3-6-15. - Procedural rules and regulations. 
    The commission shall have power to adopt rules and regulations for its own procedure and government. 
(Code 1973,  2-156) 
Sec. 3-6-16. - Powers and duties. 
    The commission shall have the power to employ such technical experts and such other agents and employees as it may require for the purpose of making studies, surveys and investigations of a suitable site on which to establish, construct and maintain an airport or landing field; to recommend to the governing bodies of the participating counties and cities a suitable site for such airport or landing field; upon the acquisition of title to such site for such airport by the participating counties and cities to care for, manage and control such airport property and its facilities including, but not by way of limitation, the authority to enter into leases, as lessor, for any land or facility embraced within such property, but not extending over a term of more than two (2) years, including renewals, unless approved by the governing bodies; to contract for mail, cargo and passenger service with the United States Government, any commercial airlines and others; to enter into employment contracts for any purpose embraced within this authority; to enter into contracts with concessionaires but not extending over a term of more than two (2) years unless approved by such governing bodies; to contract for all necessary utility services; to establish and enforce all rules and regulations pertaining to the use of the airport and its facilities; to establish and charge fees or other charges for the use of the airport, the landing field and accompanying facilities; to accept gifts and grants from the state or any political subdivision thereof, and from the United States and any of its agencies or from any person; and to designate the state corporation commission agent for the commission and the participating counties and cities to accept, receive, receipt for and disburse such funds as may be granted by the United States under the Federal Airport Act in accordance with the applicable laws, rules and regulations. 
(Code 1973,  2-157) 
Sec. 3-6-17. - Agreement as to financial basis. 
    The financial basis upon which each of the counties and cities for which the commission is formed shall participate shall be determined by agreement between their governing bodies. 
(Code 1973,  2-158) 
Sec. 3-6-18. - Budget and appropriations. 
    The commission shall prepare annually and submit to the governing bodies of the respective participating counties and cities a proposed budget showing the estimated revenues it may reasonably expect to receive for such year, and its estimated expenses for all purposes for such period. After approval of such budget the commission shall be limited in its estimated expenditures for such year to the estimated expenses shown therein; and shall not commit the participating counties and cities beyond appropriations actually made. The participating counties and cities shall appropriate funds necessary to meet any deficit in the proportions in which they are financially interested in the operations of the commission. 
(Code 1973,  2-159) 
Sec. 3-6-19. - Disbursements. 
    All disbursements by the commission shall be by check drawn by the treasurer and approved by the chairman. 
(Code 1973,  2-160) 
Sec. 3-6-20. - Records. 
    The commission shall keep proper records of its operations, dealings, transactions and meetings, which records shall be open to inspection by the participating counties and cities at all times. 
(Code 1973,  2-161) 
Sec. 3-6-21. - Reports. 
    The commission shall make reports to the participating counties and cities annually, and at such other times as they may require. 
(Code 1973,  2-162) 
Sec. 3-6-22. - Liability of members for certain acts. 
    In serving on the commission and when acting within the scope of the authority herein conferred, no member of the commission shall be personally subject to liability upon any suit or claim by any person contracting with the commission, using the airport or its facilities or damaged by the use of the airport or its facilities; and in the event of any such suit or claim against the commission or any of its members, the participating counties and cities shall be obligated in the proportions in which they are financially interested in the operation of the commission to indemnify such member or the commission from any loss which he or it may sustain. 
(Code 1973,  2-163) 
Secs. 3-6-23-3-6-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE C. - INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY 

Sec. 3-6-31. - Created; power and duties. 
    There is hereby created a political subdivision of the Commonwealth of Virginia with such public and corporate powers as are set forth in the Industrial Development and Revenue Bond Act (chapter 33, title 15.1 of the Code of Virginia, as amended), including such powers as may hereafter be granted from time to time by the General Assembly of Virginia. 
(Code 1973,  2-180) 
Sec. 3-6-32. - Named. 
    The name of the political subdivision of the commonwealth created hereby shall be the Economic Development Authority of the City of Harrisonburg, Virginia, hereafter referred to as the authority. 
(Code 1973,  2-181; Ord. of 8-23-16(1)) 
Sec. 3-6-33. - Composition, terms of office of members. 
    The board of directors of the authority shall be composed of seven (7) members appointed to four-year staggered terms of office. Terms of a board member shall expire on April 24 of the year of the term's expiration. 
Secs. 3-6-34-3-6-40. - Reserved.

CHAPTER 7. - MAYOR 

Sec. 3-7-1. - Authority of mayor to accept interests in real estate on behalf of city. 
    Pursuant to section 15.2-1803, Code of Virginia (1950), as amended, any deed purporting to convey real estate, or an interest in real estate, to the City of Harrisonburg, shall be valid only when it is accepted on behalf of the city by the mayor or city manager. Acceptance shall appear on the face of such deed or on a separately recorded instrument. 
(Ord. of 10-26-00) 
Cross reference- Authority of city manager to accept interests in real estate on behalf of city,  3-1-4. 
Title 4 - FINANCE, TAXATION, PROCUREMENT 
CHAPTER 1. - FISCAL ADMINISTRATION 
ARTICLE A. - COMMISSIONER OF THE REVENUE 

Sec. 4-1-1. - Location of office. 
    The council shall provide the commissioner of the revenue with an office which shall be located in a convenient place in the city. 
(Code 1973,  2-97) 
Charter reference- Commissioner of the revenue,  50. 
Sec. 4-1-2. - How books, records, etc., to be kept; inspection of books, records, etc. 
    Except as otherwise provided, all books, schedules, records and other papers pertaining to the work of the commissioner of the revenue shall be kept in such manner as may be prescribed by the council. Such books, schedules, records and other papers shall be subject to inspection and examination as provided by section 58.1-3 of the Code of Virginia, as amended. 
Sec. 4-1-3. - Books, forms, etc., to be used; city to furnish other books, forms, etc. 
    The commissioner of the revenue shall use the land and personal property books and other tax books and forms sent to him by the state department of taxation as provided by law, unless lawful changes in such books or forms are directed by the council. In case of such change, he shall use the books and forms prescribed and furnished by the city. The city shall furnish the commissioner all other books, forms, stationery, office supplies and equipment reasonably necessary for the proper conduct of such office. 
(Code 1973,  2-99) 
Note- Real and personal property tax books are processed and maintained by the department of data processing. 
Sec. 4-1-4. - To be tax assessor. 
    The commissioner of the revenue shall be the tax assessor for the city, in accordance with the state constitution and laws and with the ordinances, rules and regulations of the council. 
(Code 1973,  2-100) 
Sec. 4-1-5. - Assessment of real estate-Generally; preparation and delivery of land property books. 
(a)  All real estate in the city shall be assessed annually, beginning on January 1, by the commissioner of the revenue, for taxation by the city. The annual assessment of all real estate in the city shall be at its fair market value and shall include all lands, buildings, structures and improvements thereon and all rights thereto and interests therein, and the commissioner of the revenue shall have the right and power to do all things necessary to assess such property. 
(b)  Every assessment of real estate shall be effective for tax purposes on the first day of July of the fiscal year for which the assessment is made and the taxes and other charges shall be extended on the basis of such assessment. The beginning of the tax year on all real estate assessable by the city for taxation shall be July 1, and the owner of such real estate on that day shall be assessed with taxes for the fiscal year beginning on that day. 
(c)  The annual assessment made by the commissioner of the revenue shall be completed by December 1 and the assessor shall have a goal of notifying property owners whose assessment values have changed on or before the thirty-first of December of each year. The commissioner of the revenue shall prepare the real property book, in the form prescribed by the state department of taxation, showing the assessed value of all taxable real property and the value of all nontaxable real estate located within the city. The real property book shall be presented to the city treasurer not later than September 1 of each year, unless an extension of time has been granted for cause. The commissioner of the revenue may thereafter prepare such supplements to the books as may be necessary and forward them to the treasurer. 
(d)  It shall not be necessary for the assessor to prepare a reassessment book, but the records of the assessment may be kept on cards or in such other way as the city council prescribes; or, in case no such provision is made, as the assessor deems best. 
(e)  The assessor shall give the written notice, as required by subsection (c) of this section, by mailing the notice to the last known post office address of such owner in whose name the property is listed, but the validity of such assessment shall not be affected by any failure to give or receive such notice. Every such notice shall contain the assessed value of such real estate immediately preceding such increase. 
(f)  Any property owner of real property in the city shall have the right to appeal any assessment thereof to the city assessor by appointment according to a schedule set by the assessor, which schedule shall be noted on the written notice of assessment. The assessor shall have a goal to complete the appeal hearings by January 31 of the year prior to the effective day of the assessment. Any property owner remaining unsatisfied with the action taken on appeal may further appeal to the city's board of equalization by making application by appointment according to the schedule set by the board of equalization, which schedule shall be noted on the written notice of change of assessment. The city's board of equalization shall have a goal of having its work completed by April 15 of the year prior to the effective day of the assessment. Any appeal not timely filed shall not be considered. 
(Ord. of 11-24-92; Ord. of 3-23-93; Ord. of 6-13-06; Ord. of 10-9-12(1)) 
State Law reference- Arrangement and contents of books, Va. Code,  58.1-3115. 
Sec. 4-1-6. - Same-When lot subdivided. 
    When a lot becomes the property of different owners in several parcels, the value of each parcel shall be as provided by section 58.1-3342 of the Code of Virginia, as amended. 
(Code 1973,  2-102) 
Sec. 4-1-7. - Assessment of new buildings; abatement of levies on buildings razed, destroyed or damaged by fortuitous happenings. 
(a)  All new buildings shall be assessed when substantially completed and fit for use, occupancy and enjoyment and the commissioner of revenue of the city shall enter in the books the fair market value of such building; provided, that no such partial assessment shall become effective until information as to the date and amount of such assessment is recorded in the office of the city treasurer and made available for public inspection. The tax on such new building shall be computed according to the ratio which the portion of the year such building is fit for use, occupancy and enjoyment bears to the entire year, as provided and enabled by section 58.1-3292 of the Code of Virginia. 
(b)  Levies on buildings which are razed or destroyed, or damaged by a fortuitous happening beyond the control of the owner, shall be abated as provided by section 58.1-3222 of the Code of Virginia; provided, as set forth in such section, that no such abatement shall be allowed if the damage to such building shall impair the value thereof by less than five hundred dollars ($500.00); and provided further, that no such abatement shall be allowed in the case of damage to any such building if such damage shall be repaired during the same calendar year in which it occurred. The tax on such razed, destroyed or damaged building shall be computed according to the ratio which the portion of the year such building was fit for use, occupancy and enjoyment bears to the entire year. Application for such abatement shall be made by or on behalf of the owner of such building within the calendar year in which such building was razed or destroyed, or in which such damage was sustained. 
(Code 1973,  2-103) 
Sec. 4-1-8. - Assessment of improvements. 
    The commissioner of the revenue shall ascertain the value of all improvements increased in value to five hundred dollars ($500.00) or more made on real estate during each year and note the same on the assessment, which shall be assessed in the same manner as if they were new. 
Editor's note- As provided by law, buildings and enclosures that are increased by $500.00 or more are assessed as if they were new (Va. Code,  58-812). Former section provided $100.00. 
Sec. 4-1-9. - Assessment of personal property-Tax and return dates. 
(a)  In ascertaining what personal property is to be listed for taxation the laws of the state and the city's annual appropriation ordinance shall be followed. 
(b)  All tangible personal property, machinery and tools subject to city taxation shall be assessed as of January 1 of each year and the status of all such taxpayers fixed as of that date. 
(c)  On or before March 31 of each year, every owner of tangible personal property or machinery and tools subject to taxation shall file with the commissioner of the revenue, on forms prescribed by the commissioner of the revenue, an itemized list of such property with such descriptions, valuations and cost figures as the form shall require. Lessees of taxable property shall file returns listing the name and address of the owner. The commissioner of the revenue may grant, upon application by the taxpayer, for good cause shown, in the discretion of the commissioner, an extension of up to ninety (90) days for the filing of returns on tangible personal property, machinery and tools after the March 31 deadline. 
(d)  The commissioner of the revenue and the city treasurer may approve a combined form for the return of personal property and machinery and tools and the registration and purchase of license decals and parking permits for motor vehicles garaged or parked in the city. All costs of preparing and mailing said combined forms shall be shared equally between the commissioner of the revenue and the city treasurer. Presentation, in person or by mail, to the city treasurer of such combined form, when properly completed and signed at the time of purchase of the city license decal shall be deemed to constitute filing of the personal property tax return with the commissioner of the revenue. 
(Code 1973,  2-105; Ord. of 12-16-97; Res. of 5-13-03) 
Sec. 4-1-10. - Same-Lists of valuation to be furnished and returned to commissioner. 
    The commissioner of the revenue shall furnish to each person forms for lists of valuations as provided for by state laws, who shall within the time and in the manner therein specified, make out and deliver to the commissioner sworn statements of all personal estate, monies, contracts and credits which such person is required by the state laws to list. The form of oath shall be the same as is prescribed by state law and the commissioner of the revenue and his deputies shall have power to administer the same. 
(Code 1973,  2-106) 
Sec. 4-1-11. - Same-Revaluation of property. 
    If the commissioner of the revenue be not satisfied with the taxpayer's valuation of property, he may upon his own view, or such information as he may obtain or possess, adopt what he deems a fair and proper valuation thereof; provided, that where it is practicable he shall give an opportunity to the taxpayer to be heard before his books are returned as provided in this article. 
(Code 1973,  2-107) 
Sec. 4-1-12. - Same-Penalty for failure to make return or failure to exhibit property. 
    If any person shall fail within the required time to deliver the application, return or lists in the manner prescribed, or if any person shall refuse to exhibit to the commissioner of the revenue any property listed, or required by this chapter to be listed, by him, in order that a fair valuation thereof may be assessed, he shall pay a penalty of ten (10) percent of the tax assessable on such return or the sum of ten dollars ($10.00), whichever is greater; provided, however, that the penalty shall in no case exceed the amount of the tax assessable. The penalty for failure to file an application or return may be assessed on the day after such return or application is due. Any such penalty when so assessed shall become a part of the tax. 
(Code 1973,  2-108; Ord. of 11-26-91; Ord. of 12-8-92) 
Sec. 4-1-13. - State law to be followed as to land and personal property books. 
    The land and personal property books shall be made up, examined, certified and delivered as provided by the state law. 
(Code 1973,  2-109) 
Sec. 4-1-14. - Reports to department of finance. 
    The commissioner of the revenue shall as soon as practicable, file a report with the department of finance of a list of licenses issued by him, the total assessments of property within the city, reports of abatements of taxes, reports of cancellations or adjustments of licenses and any other reports which the director of finance may deem necessary in the performance of his duties. 
(Code 1973,  2-112; Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-15. - Board of equalization-Appointment, composition, term, etc. 
    There shall be created a permanent board of equalization for the city, which board shall consist of three (3) members, recommended by the city council and appointed by the Circuit Court of Rockingham County, Virginia. The initial board shall be appointed as follows: one (1) member shall be appointed for a term of one (1) year, one (1) member shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years and one (1) member shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years. As the terms of the initial appointees expire, their successors shall be appointed for terms of three (3) years. Members of the board shall have the qualifications as prescribed by section 58.1-3374 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended, and shall organize and conduct their business as required by sections 58.1-3376 and 58.1-3378 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended. Compensation of the members of the board shall be fixed by the city council. The board shall sit and hear appeals between January 1 and June 30 of each year. 
(Ord. of 6-13-06) 
Secs. 4-1-16-4-1-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - CITY TREASURER[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- City treasurer,  50. 

Sec. 4-1-21. - Council to provide books, stationery, etc. 
    The council shall provide the treasurer with suitable books, stationery and office equipment for the safe and convenient keeping of all books, documents and papers in their custody and for the proper and efficient transaction of the affairs and business of the office. 
(Code 1973,  2-113; Ord. of 7-22-08(1)) 
Sec. 4-1-22. - Inspection of books, accounts, etc. 
    All books, accounts, documents and papers pertaining to the business of the city, and kept in the treasurer's office shall be subject at all times to inspection as provided by section 58.1-3127 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended. 
(Ord. of 7-22-08(1)) 
Sec. 4-1-23. - Powers and duties generally. 
    The treasurer shall collect all taxes, assessments and penalties, and income and revenues due the city, also any other income or revenue the collections of which is made the duty of some other officer by resolution or ordinance of the council, or as otherwise determined by the city manager and director of finance. The treasurer shall receive all taxes and other revenues and money which it is their duty to collect from persons owing the same to the city or which it is the duty of other officers to collect and pay over to them. The treasurer shall deposit those funds as per section 4-1-35 of this Code and further the treasurer shall not cash any checks for any person, partnership, corporation, limited liability company or any other legal entity using city funds. The treasurer shall keep their office in such place within the city as is provided for the treasurer by the city council. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93; Ord. of 7-22-08(1)) 
Sec. 4-1-24. - Receipt of city revenue, etc. 
    Except as otherwise provided, all revenues and income belonging to or accruing to the city shall be paid to and received by the city treasurer at their office during regular office hours. Certain departmental collections may be deposited directly to the bank, if the director of finance determines that this is what should be done and the treasurer's office is not open during its regular office hours. 
(Code 1973,  9-11; Ord. of 2-23-82; Ord. of 4-27-93; Ord. of 7-22-08(1)) 
Sec. 4-1-25. - Preparation and disposition of tax receipts. 
    From the books of the commissioner of the revenue, the treasurer shall make off for each taxpayer shown therein a tax receipt, substantially in the form prescribed by the state department of taxation. Upon collecting such tax, they shall deliver to the taxpayer such tax receipt, showing plainly the date of payment, unless the payment is made by mail then the treasurer, shall mail a tax receipt, showing plainly the date of payment, if a self-addressed envelope is included with the payment. 
(Ord. of 7-22-08(1)) 
State Law reference- Delivery of tax ticket upon payment of taxes, Va. Code,  58-959; collection of taxes by treasurer, Va. Code,  59-958. 
Sec. 4-1-26. - Statement of city taxes to be mailed to taxpayer. 
    As soon as practicable, and not later than fourteen (14) days prior to the due date, the treasurer shall mail or send to each taxpayer assessed with a city tax a statement of the taxes in the required form. 
(Code 1973,  9-13; Ord. of 11-24-92; Ord. of 7-22-08(1)) 
Sec. 4-1-27. - Collection of taxes generally; when taxes due; interest and penalty on taxes. 
(a)  The payment of taxes on real estate shall be on a fiscal-year basis from July 1 to June 30 and shall be payable in equal installments on December 5 and June 5. The assessment of all taxable real estate, pursuant to section 4-1-5 of this Code, shall become effective for tax collection purposes on the first day of July of each year. 
(b)  The payment of taxes on tangible personal property shall be on a calendar year basis and shall be on December 5. 
(c)  Any person failing to pay the city levies on or before December 5 or June 5 as required, shall incur a penalty thereon of ten (10) percent or ten dollars ($10.00), which ever is greater, which shall be added to the amount of taxes or levies due from such taxpayer, however, the penalty shall in no case exceed the amount of tax due. Interest at the rate of ten (10) percent per annum for real estate taxes and four (4) percent per annum for personal property taxes, on such principal and penalty shall begin to accrue as of the first day of the month after the unpaid tax was due, which shall be either January 1 or July 1. All penalties and interest accrued on tax payments made to the treasurer shall be collected and accounted for by the treasurer. 
(Code 1973,  9-14; Ord. of 12-9-80; Ord. of 11-24-92; Ord. of 3-23-93; Ord. of 12-16-97; Ord. of 6-13-06; Ord. of 7-22-08(1)) 
Cross reference- Duties of treasurer as to collection of license taxes,  12-1-7. 
Sec. 4-1-28. - Submission of certain lists to council; oath to be contained in lists; etc. 
(a)  The treasurer shall annually prepare and submit to the council at its regular June meeting a list showing: 
(1)  Real estate, if any, on the land book of the commissioner of the revenue, improperly placed thereon, or not ascertainable, with amount of taxes and levies charged thereon. 
(2)  Real estate on which taxes are delinquent. 
(3)  All tangible personal property, machinery and tools, merchants capital or other subjects, if any which are segregated to the city for local taxation, exclusively, and which assessments the treasurer is unable to collect. 
(b)  These lists shall speak as of June 30 of each year, that is to say, the facts stated shall conform to the facts as they were on that day. 
(c)  Such lists shall contain the oath of the treasurer in the following form: 
"I, ___________, Treasurer of the City of Harrisonburg, do swear that the foregoing lists are, I verily believe, correct and just; that I have received no part of the taxes for which the real and personal property therein mentioned is returned delinquent; and that although I have used due diligence to collect said taxes and levies, no part of the same has been collected by me. 
___________, Treasurer" 
(d)  The council or an agent thereof, shall examine such lists and if the lists are found to be correct, the council by proper resolution shall allow the treasurer credit in their settlements for the amounts thereof. The treasurer shall deliver a copy of the first of such lists to the commissioner of the revenue, who shall correct their books accordingly. 
(Code 1973,  9-15; Ord. of 7-22-08(1)) 
Sec. 4-1-29. - Advertisement of delinquent real estate taxes. 
    After the city treasurer has submitted to the city council the delinquent real estate tax list as required by section 4-1-28, the city council shall require all real estate in the city on which delinquent taxes or assessments are due to be advertised once in the Daily News-Record with the costs of said publication being charged on a pro-rata basis to the delinquent taxpayers listed on said tax list. Said advertisement shall be made by the city treasurer at the direction of the city council and not later than sixty (60) days after the first and second anniversaries of the delinquency. 
(Code 1973,  9-16; Ord. of 12-16-97; Ord. of 7-22-08(1)) 
Sec. 4-1-30. - Distress, levy and garnishment for unpaid taxes, assessments, etc. 
    For the purpose of collecting taxes, assessments, licenses and other dues to the city, the treasurer shall have the right of distress, levy, garnishment and third party collections and associated costs as provided by state law. All property subject to levy to satisfy taxes, assessments, licenses and other duties to the state may be taken to satisfy taxes, assessments, licenses and other dues to the city. 
(Code 1973,  9-17; Ord. of 11-12-02; Ord. of 7-22-08(1)) 
State Law reference- Distress for taxes generally, Va. Code,  58-965, 58-101-58-1013. 
Sec. 4-1-31. - Daily reports. 
    The city treasurer shall report to the director of finance daily on forms entitled "Daily Cash Settlement", all collections by types and funds for the preceding day showing the source from which such funds were derived, the bank in which such funds were deposited and shall submit with such report copies of receipts which were issued, copy of bank deposit receipts and any other evidence of payment or receipt which may be deemed advisable by the city treasurer or the director of finance. 
(Ord. of 4-27-92; Ord. of 7-22-08(1)) 
Sec. 4-1-32. - Monthly reports. 
    The city treasurer shall, prior to the second Tuesday of each and every month, file with the director of finance a report of a trial balance as of the last day of the preceding month, showing a list of the balances of the accounts comprising their general ledger and bank deposits. 
(Code 1973,  2-116.1; Ord. of 4-27-93; Ord. of 7-22-08(1)) 
Sec. 4-1-33. - Additional reports. 
    The city treasurer shall make any additional reports that may be deemed necessary from time to time by the city manager or the director of finance. 
(Code 1973,  2-117; Ord. of 4-12-94; Ord. of 7-22-08(1)) 
Sec. 4-1-34. - Canceled checks. 
    The city treasurer shall file and keep in their office all of the city's canceled checks or facsimiles thereof. 
(Code 1973,  2-118; Ord. of 4-27-93; Ord. of 7-22-08(1)) 
Sec. 4-1-35. - Depositories. 
    The commercial banks engaged in business in the city are hereby designated as depositories of city funds; provided, that each of them meets the requirements of the Virginia Code for the deposit of public funds. The city treasurer is hereby authorized and directed to deposit the funds of the city in these banks, which funds so deposited may be withdrawn upon a check, draft or order of the city, signed by the director of finance and countersigned by the city treasurer. The city's general bank account shall be with one (1) of these banks based upon a banking service contract, awarded pursuant to the city procurement ordinance, which contracts shall commence on July 1. These contracts shall be for a period of three (3) years, with an option to renew for additional years, but not to exceed six (6) years in total. 
(Code 1973,  9-18; Ord. of 8-10-99; Ord. of 7-22-08(1)) 
Sec. 4-1-36. - Continuing collection of delinquent taxes. 
(a)  The city treasurer shall continue to collect the taxes shown on the delinquent tax lists for one (1) year following June 30 of the year as of which such delinquent lists speak. 
(b)  At the expiration of one (1) year following June 30 of the year of which such delinquent lists speak; the city treasurer shall again submit a copy of each of the lists mentioned in section 4-1-28 of this article to the city council. Such lists so resubmitted shall show the changes which have occurred since June 30 of the preceding year, and the city treasurer shall continue to collect the unpaid real estate taxes until the real estate shall be sold under the provisions of the Code of Virginia, Article 4 of Chapter 39 (section 58.1-3965 et seq.) of Title 58.1. 
(c)  The city attorney shall assist the treasurer in bringing suit to sell lands delinquent in excess of two (2) years as provided by state law. The treasurer is authorized to post the necessary bonds for such attorney to act as special commissioner for the sale of delinquent lands. 
(d)  After the second listing of delinquent taxes on personal property, machinery and tools the treasurer shall continue to collect the same for an additional two (2) years. At the end of that time the treasurer shall return an updated delinquent list to city council and after review by the city council, the treasurer shall be given credit for such amounts and shall not be required to make further collections thereon. 
(Res. of 10-13-64; Ord. of 7-22-08(1)) 
Sec. 4-1-37. - Administrative fee for passing bad checks or drafts. 
    Any person uttering, publishing or passing any check or draft for payment of taxes or any other sums due the city, which is subsequently returned for insufficient funds or because there is no account or the account has been closed or payment has been stopped shall be charged a fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00). 
(Res. of 11-23-66; Res. of 5-12-70; Ord. of 2-12-85; Ord. of 4-27-93; Ord. of 7-22-08(1)) 
Secs. 4-1-38, 4-1-39. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. of 7-22-08(1), repealed  4-1-38 and 4-1-39, which pertained to continuing collection of delinquent taxes and administration fee for passing bad checks of drafts. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 4-1-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE C. - RESERVED[2] 

Footnotes:
