Secs. 4-1-41-4-1-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE D. - DIRECTOR OF FINANCE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance enacted Apr. 27, 1993, amended and re-enacted Ch. 4-1, Art. D to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, Art. D contained provisions which pertained to the city auditor and was derived from provisions presumably enacted during the 1979 codification, and from Code 1973,  2-68, 2-70-2-72, 2-74-2-78, 2-80-2-87, 2-89 and 2-90. 

Secs. 4-1-51, 4-1-52. - Reserved. 
Sec. 4-1-53. - Inspection of records, etc., in custody of director of finance. 
    All books, records and papers in the custody of the director of finance shall be open to inspection subject to all of the terms and conditions of the Virginia Freedom of Information Act. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-54. - Duties generally. 
    The director of finance is specially charged with the maintenance of the faith and credit of the city, and the preservation of all books, papers and other data relating to its public debt and other liabilities, and shall do and perform any and all other acts and things not inconsistent with the provisions of the ordinances which are proper to accomplish the fiscal objects contemplated herein. The director of finance, upon the request of the city manager, shall attend all regular meetings of the council and shall superintend and be responsible for the proper and accurate keeping of all accounts and fiscal records of the city. The director of finance shall keep all accounts necessary to reflect at all times the resources, obligations, revenues, expenditures and unappropriated fund balances. Such accounts shall be kept, by detail and funds, in such a manner as to show at all times the estimated revenue, realized revenue and unrealized estimated revenue, and the appropriations, expenditures, encumbrances and unencumbered appropriations for each department and agency of the city government. Appropriations shall be classified by departments, functions and departmental bureaus or agencies; and expenditures by objects within each department, function and departmental bureau or agency. He shall keep complete records reflecting the financial condition and the results of operations of the water and sewer utilities, and such other records as the council, city manager or he may deem necessary and advisable. All records shall be maintained, insofar as practicable, in accordance with accepted principles and procedures prescribed for municipalities. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-55. - Tentative estimate of revenue. 
    The director of finance shall, by March 1 of each year, prepare and submit to the city manager a tentative estimate of all revenues of each fund showing the actual amount of revenue received from each source the preceding year, the estimated revenue of the current fiscal year and the tentative estimate of revenue for the ensuing fiscal year and as to whether it is an increase or decrease over or under the estimate of the current fiscal year and a written explanation or reason therefor. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-56. - Publication of yearly statement. 
    The director of finance shall prepare and publish, once a year, in a newspaper of the city, a condensed statement of the city's cash receipts and disbursements as of the end of such fiscal year. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-57. - Charging and crediting city treasurer. 
    The director of finance shall charge the city treasurer with the whole amount of taxes of all types, including penalties, and licenses of all types, including penalties, which it is the duty of such officer to endeavor to collect and shall credit him or her with all collections made by him or her and accounted for to the director of finance. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-58. - Execution of checks. 
(a)  The director of finance shall prepare and countersign all checks, which shall be prenumbered for all city purposes, subject to the restrictions and regulations of the city ordinances and general laws. The director of finance and the city treasurer shall countersign the checks of the city and the city treasurer shall sign such checks on the authorization of the director of finance, which authorization shall consist of the signature of the director of finance on a check prepared and sent to the office of the city treasurer by the director of finance. 
(b)  The director of finance shall not be required to prepare and countersign any checks for the Harrisonburg City School Board as the board in an independent and autonomous body. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-59. - Prerequisites to approval of purchase orders, payrolls, etc. 
    The director of finance shall not approve any purchase order, payroll or invoice for materials, supplies, equipment or other things or services for any department unless there shall be to the credit of such department, bureau, agency or individual on the books and records of the director of finance an unencumbered appropriation sufficient to pay for all such materials, supplies, equipment and other things or services to be purchased or has been purchased or performed or rendered. In the event of an unencumbered appropriation balance being insufficient to cover the proposed purchase or payment of services rendered, the director of finance shall return the purchase order or invoice to the purchasing agent, or the payroll to the department, bureau or agency submitting the same, with a written notation stating the reason therefor. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-60. - Procedure for payment of invoices, payrolls, etc., generally. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided, the director of finance shall pay such invoices and other claims against the city as are properly approved by the city purchasing agent or his duly designated assistant if the available balances of the respective appropriation accounts to which they are chargeable will permit, unless there is a question of legality, in which case the item may be paid only on the opinion of the city attorney that it is a legal obligation of the city. 
(b)  The payment of all invoices, payrolls and accounts due by the city shall be made by means of checks or electronic transfers as prepared by the director of finance, payable to the vendor, unless the invoice or payroll or any part of it is applied toward the payment of an account owed the city by the vendor or payee, and drawn on the bank designated by the city treasurer and in an amount not in excess of the amount of the invoice or payroll after deductions for discount and other credit or other types of deductions have been made. 
(c)  After the payment of invoices and payrolls, the director of finance shall note on the original copy of the same the date that it was paid, the check number or electronic transfer number by which it was paid, and he shall retain the original copy in his office on file in proper order for inspection at any time. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93; Ord. of 7-12-94) 
Sec. 4-1-61. - Procedure as to payment for service rendered, work done, etc., by city department or bureau. 
    Whenever any bureau, department or agency renders any service, sells any product or performs any work for any person, it shall report the same to the office of the director of finance and submit an itemized and detailed report of such account. The department, bureau or agency shall render therefor an account in quadruplicate, one copy shall be presented to the person for whom the services were rendered, the work performed or to whom the product was sold, one copy to the city treasurer, one copy to the director of finance, who shall charge the treasurer therewith, and one copy shall be retained by the department performing the work, rendering the service or selling the product, and whenever any bureau or department renders any services, sells any product or performs any work for any person for which payment is made in cash, a statement thereof in quadruplicate shall be prepared by such bureau or department, one copy shall be presented to the city treasurer together with the cash and his receipt retained, one copy to the person to whom the services were rendered, the product sold or the work performed, one copy to the director of finance who shall charge the city treasurer therewith, and one copy retained by the department rendering the service, performing the work or selling the product, and a receipt given to the person making the payment. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-62. - Acceptance of invoices. 
(a)  All invoices for materials, supplies, equipment or other things or services purchased by the city, other than salaries, and not otherwise exempt under the provision requiring that a purchase order be issued and approved prior to the time when the materials, supplies, equipment, services or other items are purchased, shall be approved in writing by the city purchasing agent, who shall certify that the materials, supplies, equipment, services or other items purchased have been received in good condition or services performed, that payment therefor has not been previously authorized, and that the expenditure is a proper charge to the appropriate account indicated on the invoice and is to be presented to the office of the director of finance for payment. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the director of finance to examine all invoices so presented, check the same against the purchase orders, receiving reports and other documents pertaining thereto, and generally to satisfy himself as to the correctness of all expenditure documents. He also shall observe and deduct all available discounts, allowances, exemptions or other credits, if any. He then shall approve, certify and prepare for payment such of the invoices as are correct and should be paid. Should any invoice be incorrect, the director of finance shall contact the city purchasing agent for correction, except in cases of mathematical errors, in which cases the director of finance shall correct the errors and notify the vendor of his action, approve and pay the invoices as soon as possible or whenever due. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-63. - Payment of bonds and notes and interest thereon. 
    The director of finance shall prepare an invoice and pay the interest due by the city upon its bonds and notes to the holders thereof as the same becomes due and payable. The director of finance shall also pay all notes and bonds of the city as they become due to the holders thereof, provided that there are sufficient funds with which to pay the same. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-64. - Disposition of canceled coupons, bonds and notes. 
    The director of finance, after first satisfying himself that all coupons, bonds and notes are duly canceled, shall file and safely keep the same until their destruction is directed by council. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-65. - Establishment of paydays. 
    The director of finance, at the direction of the city manager, shall establish the dates on which all persons on the city payrolls will receive their pay checks. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-66. - When payrolls to be submitted to director of finance. 
    The director of finance shall not be required to pay any payrolls, or any part thereof, of any department, bureau or agency unless the same is presented for proper verification within the time periods to be set by the director of finance. If any such payroll is submitted later than the designated times, the director of finance may withhold paying such payroll in its entirety until the following date on which any payrolls are regularly paid, excepting instances of delay being caused by emergency or where it is impossible to do otherwise as the circumstances may justify. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-67. - Preparation of checks, etc. 
    The director of finance shall, on such date as he may determine, having due regard to the date the same are to be delivered and to any other factor incident thereto or connected therewith, prepare checks for the total amount in the case of commissions or legal fees. Further, the director of finance shall issue checks in the names and for the amounts shown on the payrolls submitted by each department head or official who shall certify that the employees or officials listed on the payroll submitted are persons regularly employed in the service of the city under such official's supervision and direction in his department during the period stated on such payroll and that the amounts shown due are in accordance with the duly authorized rates of compensation by appropriation or order of the council or city manager. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-68. - Acceptance of withholding tax certificates, etc. 
    The director of finance, if any employee or department head on behalf of any employee does not file in the director of finance's office a withholding tax certificate or any other requirement of the state or federal government on the day before a payroll is to be regularly paid, shall not be required to accept such certificate or to give in any effect until the following payroll period or in accordance with the legal requirements in regard thereto. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-69. - Deductions from accounts, etc., for amounts due city. 
    The director of finance shall deduct from any and all accounts and all salaries due by the city any amount which may be due the city and to pay the vendor or the employee the balance of his account due after deducting the amount due the city by any such person, if any. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-70. - Deductions from payrolls, etc., for taxes, etc. 
    The director of finance is authorized in the payment of all invoices, payrolls and accounts to deduct or withhold all taxes and other legal deductions authorized or directed in accordance with the ordinances of the city, or state or federal laws. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-71. - Unpaid accounts to be turned over to collector of delinquent taxes. 
    The director of finance is hereby authorized to turn over to the collector of delinquent taxes for collection all unpaid water and sewer accounts on which deposits have been applied toward the payment in instances where the consumer had a deposit, unpaid water and sewer accounts where the consumer did not have a deposit, unpaid sidewalk accounts, sewer and water connection accounts, accounts for the sale of materials and supplies sold or services rendered or any other accounts of any nature or description which are due the city for a period of ninety (90) days and which have been placed in the office of the director of finance. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-72. - Reports-Information afforded by other city officers. 
    To enable him to make up either his monthly, annual or any special report requested by the city manager or city council, the director of finance is authorized to call on the city attorney, treasurer, commissioner of the revenue or any other officer of the city for any information books, records or accounts in their possession which he may deem necessary for the proper discharge of such duty. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-73. - Same-Monthly financial reports. 
    The director of finance shall prepare and submit monthly financial reports to the mayor, members of the city council, the city manager and department heads showing the general status of all city funds as to the last day of the preceding calendar month. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-74. - Same-Annual reports. 
    The director of finance shall prepare an annual report in which shall be shown the financial condition of all funds of the city as of the close of the fiscal year in regard to receipts and disbursements and the results of operation of all funds for the fiscal year. This report shall be submitted to the council and the city manager not later than December 31 after the close of the fiscal year. 
(Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-1-75. - Investing of city funds. 
    When directed to do so by the city manager the director of finance shall invest funds of the city as per section 2.2-4602 and Chapter 46 of Title 2.2 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended. All funds so directed shall be invested to the credit of the city. 
(Ord. of 7-22-08(2)) 
Secs. 4-1-76, 4-1-77. - Reserved. 
CHAPTER 2. - REVENUE AND TAXATION[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Power of council to control and manage the fiscal affairs of the city,  11; annual taxes and assessments,  12; collection of taxes,  36; budget generally,  59 et seq. 

ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 4-2-1. - Consent and approval of council prerequisite to exceeding appropriation. 
    No department, bureau, agency or individual receiving appropriations under the provision of the annual budget and appropriations bill of each year shall exceed the amount of its or his appropriation except with the consent and approval of the council first obtained. If any such bureau, department, agency or individual shall exceed the amount of its or his appropriation without such consent and approval of the council, the department, bureau or agency head or individual, in the discretion of the council shall be subject to disciplinary action therefor. 
(Code 1973,  9-1) 
Sec. 4-2-2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 4-2-2, pertaining to investment of excess working funds, proceeds from sale of bonds, etc., and derived from Code 1973,  9-2, was repealed by an ordinance of Apr. 27, 1993. 
Sec. 4-2-3. - Proration of fund appropriations. 
    Except as otherwise provided, all appropriations made each fiscal year out of the general fund, the state public assistance fund, the city school fund, the water fund and the sewer fund, are declared to be maximum, conditional and proportionate appropriations, the purpose being to make the appropriations payable in full in the amounts named in the budget ordinance each year if necessary and, then, only in the event the aggregate revenues collected and available during the respective fiscal year for which the appropriations are made are sufficient to pay all of the appropriations in full. Otherwise, such appropriations shall be deemed to be payable in such proportion as the total sum of all realized revenue of the general fund, state public assistance fund, city school fund, water fund and sewer fund is to the total amount of the revenues estimated to be available in such fiscal year by the council, the city school board and the board of public welfare. 
(Code 1973,  9-3) 
Sec. 4-2-4. - Unexpended and unencumbered balances. 
    All balances of the appropriations payable out of the general fund of the city treasury unexpended or unencumbered at the close of business on June 30 of each year, the last day of the fiscal year, except as otherwise provided for, are hereby declared to be lapsed into the city treasury and shall be used for the payment of the appropriations which may be made in the appropriation ordinance or budget for the following fiscal year or for any purpose for which the council may direct. Nothing in this section shall be construed to be applicable to unexpended or unencumbered balances remaining to the credit of the city school fund, the workmen's compensation insurance fund, the sinking fund, any funds created by the setting up of special revenues or the capital project funds set up by section 4-2-10 of this Code, but such balances shall be used in financing the proposed expenditures of these funds for the ensuing fiscal year unless otherwise directed or authorized by the council. 
(Code 1973,  9-4; Ord. of 4-12-94) 
Sec. 4-2-5. - Payment into treasury of money collected by city departments, etc., generally. 
    Except as otherwise provided, all money collected by any department, bureau, agency or individual of the city government shall be paid into the city treasury not later than the day immediately following the day of collection, Sundays and holidays excepted. 
(Code 1973,  9-5) 
Sec. 4-2-6. - Transfer of cash or appropriation between and within funds. 
    No cash or appropriation transfer between funds shall be made or entered into the books of account except by appropriate resolution of the city council; provided, that the individual or department desiring such transfer or appropriation of funds shall first present a request therefore to the director of finance and the city manager for their approval or disapproval. However, transfers of appropriations within a fund may be made by the city manager, except as noted in section 4-2-10. 
(Code 1973,  9-6; Ord. of 5-11-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. of May 11, 2010, amended  4-2-6 title to read as herein set out. Former  4-2-6 title pertained to transfer of cash or appropriation between funds or departments. 
Sec. 4-2-7. - Disposition of money collected by central garage. 
    All money collected by the central garage during each fiscal year from the sale of services, commodities and other properties shall be appropriated to the central garage and shall be used for the purpose of meeting the necessary operating expenses and replacing the merchandise, materials or supplies sold. 
(Code 1973,  9-7) 
Cross reference- Central garage, Title 6, Ch. 4. 
Sec. 4-2-8. - Water and sewer reserves for capital improvements. 
(a)  There shall be established by the city council in the water and sewer funds, respectively, a reserve for capital improvements. The city manager shall provide for these funds in each year's budget of cash provided from the depreciation of the respective utilities as directed by council. 
(b)  No funds shall be transferred from such water or sewer reserve accounts of the budget of each year, nor shall any charges be made against such reserves of the water or sewer funds until recommended by the city manager and approved by the recorded majority vote of the council. These reserve funds may be transferred from one utility to another by a recorded majority vote of the council. The above funds or appropriations shall not be used in any fund other than a utility fund. 
(c)  All money now in the water and sewer funds set aside in the reserve for depreciation accounts shall be transferred to the above water and sewer reserves for capital improvements immediately on October 13, 1959. 
(Code 1973,  9-8) 
Sec. 4-2-9. - Contributions to outside agencies and charitable organizations. 
    Each outside agency or charitable organization to which the city council makes an annual contribution, or which desires an annual contribution from the city council, shall submit by January 30 of each year a written financial statement showing the sources of revenue and actual expenditures of the agency or charitable organization for its current fiscal year and a written request of the amount of contribution it desires from the council for the ensuing fiscal year beginning on July 1 next thereafter. The financial statements and written requests shall thereafter be referred to the city manager who shall consider them in the preparation of the city's budget for the ensuing fiscal year and shall not consider any similar requests unless the provisions of this section are complied with. 
(Code 1973,  9-9) 
Sec. 4-2-10. - Capital project funds and Community Development Block Grant funds. 
    For any capital projects which have a cost exceeding two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) or more, and which have a completion date of more than one fiscal year there shall be established capital project fund(s) by the city council in each year's budget. All monies budgeted in any capital project fund will be encumbered until the project is completed and will not revert back to the original appropriating fund at the end of any fiscal year. Upon completion of the project any unexpended funds shall be transferred back to the original appropriating fund. 
    For Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) funds, whose grant period does not coincide with the city's fiscal year, there shall be established funds by the city council in each year's budget. All unexpended budgeted funds for the CDBG purposes may be re-appropriated (carried forward) each fiscal year without city council approval, until the grant period is completed in accordance with the appropriate federal grant requirements. Upon completion of the grant period, any unexpended budgeted funds shall expire from the budget. 
(Ord. of 4-12-94; Ord. of 6-27-06) 
Sec. 4-2-11. - Escrow securities required by depositories for city funds. 
    The depositories for city funds are hereby required to comply with the requirements of Chapter 23 of Title 2.1 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended. When deposits are made in accordance with this chapter of the state code no treasurer shall be liable for any loss thereof resulting from the failure or default of any depository in the absence of negligence, malfeasance, misfeasance or nonfeasance on his or her part or on the part of his or her assistants or employees. 
(Code 1973,  9-10.2; Ord. of 4-27-93) 
Sec. 4-2-12. - Law library established; assessment on civil actions for its maintenance. 
(a)  As authorized by Section 42.1-70 of the Code of Virginia, there is hereby assessed as a part of the costs incident to each civil action filed in the Circuit Court of Rockingham County, Virginia, and the General District Court of Rockingham County, Virginia, the sum of four dollars ($4.00). This assessment shall be used for the establishment, use and maintenance of a law library, which shall be open for the use of the public at hours convenient to the public. This assessment shall be in addition to all other costs, as prescribed by law, on civil actions filed, but shall not apply to any action in which the Commonwealth of Virginia or any political subdivision thereof or the federal government is a party and in which the costs are assessed against the Commonwealth of Virginia, a political subdivision thereof, or the federal government. 
(b)  The library known as the "Laird L. Conrad Memorial Library" that is presently located within the Massanutten Regional Library in Harrisonburg, Virginia, was previously established and recognized as a "public law library" for purposes of Sections 17.1-275 and 42.1-70 of the Code of Virginia. This library shall be the designated public law library for purposes of the assessment for so long as it remains open for the use of the public at hours convenient to the public. 
(c)  The clerks of the courts shall collect the assessment authorized herein on each civil action filed in their respective court. The clerks shall remit the assessments collected by them to the Treasurer of Rockingham County, Virginia, ("county treasurer") as required by Sections 17.1-275 and 42.1-70 of the Code of Virginia. 
(d)  The county treasurer shall hold the remitted assessments in a fund that is subject to appropriation for disbursement by the board of supervisors of Rockingham County, Virginia, (the "board") for the purposes permitted under Section 42.1-70 of the Code of Virginia, including but not limited to the acquisition of law books, law periodicals, computer legal research services, and equipment for the use of the above established law library. There shall be established a law library committee composed of five (5) members; two (2) members of the Harrisonburg-Rockingham County Bar Association, two (2) members of the Massanutten Library Board (one (1) of which shall be a county resident and one (1) a resident of the City of Harrisonburg), and the head librarian of the Massanutten Regional Library, or designee, ex-officio. Not later than February 15 of each year the committee shall prepare an annual budget for the law library and submit it to the Rockingham County Administrator for consideration by the board. As permitted under Section 42.1-70 of the Code of Virginia, disbursements from the fund may include compensation to be paid to librarians and other necessary staff for the maintenance of the law library and maintenance of suitable quarters for the law library. 
(e)  Once appropriated by the board, the county treasurer shall disburse the fees collected under this section to the treasurer of the Massanutten Regional Library (the "library treasurer"). Funds shall be disbursed to the library treasurer upon the presentment of a statement of expenses paid. Only those expenses within the amount and purpose in the approved budget shall be paid. 
(f)  Pursuant to Section 42.1-70 of the Code of Virginia, bar associations are permitted to contribute to the assessment fund created herein. Upon receipt of such funds by the county, the board shall appropriate the funds for use by the committee as authorized in this section. 
(g)  The county treasurer and library treasurer shall provide an annual accounting to the library committee of all assessments and contributions received and disbursed for the fiscal year. The accounting shall be provided no later than December 15 following the end of the fiscal year, which ends on June 30. 
(Code 1973,  9-20; Ord. of 7-28-81; Ord. of 1-24-89; Ord. of 4-28-09(1)) 
Editor's note- Ord. of 4-28-09(1), amended  4-2-12 title to read as herein set out. Former  4-2-12 title pertained to court costs assessments for acquisition of law books, etc. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 4-2-13. - Tax on recordation of deeds. 
    There is hereby imposed and levied by the city, subject to the provisions, conditions and exceptions of Section 58-865.1 of the Code of Virginia, a city recordation tax in an amount equal to one-third ( 1/3 ) the amount of the state recordation tax collectible for the state on the first recordation of each taxable instrument in the city. 
(Code 1973,  9-21) 
Sec. 4-2-14. - General retail sales tax. 
(a)  There is hereby levied and imposed in addition to all other taxes and fees of every kind now imposed, a general retail sales tax at the rate of one (1) percent to provide revenue for the general fund. The rate of the tax shall be added to the Code of Virginia (Virginia Retail Sales and Use Tax Act) and shall be subject to all the provisions of such chapter, and all amendments thereof, and the rules and regulations published with respect thereto; except, that the applicable brackets of prices shall be as prescribed in Sections 58-441.50 and 58-441.51 of the Code of Virginia for the combined tax; and except, that no discount under Section 58-441.25 of the Code of Virginia shall be allowed on the tax levied by this section. 
(b)  It is the purpose of the council in adopting this section to levy the general retail sales tax authorized to be levied by Section 58-441.49 of the Code of Virginia. 
(Code 1973,  9-22) 
State Law reference- Virginia Retail Sales and Use Tax, Va. Code, Ch. 8.1. 
Sec. 4-2-15. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 4-2-15, pertaining to investment of excess funds by city treasurer and derived from an ordinance of Mar. 11, 1980, was repealed by an ordinance of Apr. 27, 1993. 
Sec. 4-2-16. - Tax on criminal and traffic cases. 
(a)  There is hereby imposed and levied by the city, subject to the provisions of Section 17.1-281 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended, an additional fee of two dollars ($2.00) to be taxed as costs in any civil, criminal or traffic case prosecuted on a city warrant or summons, in either the circuit court, general district court or the juvenile and domestic relations court. This additional assessment shall be for the maintenance, construction or renovation of a courthouse, jail or court-related facilities and to defray increases in costs of cooling, heating, electricity and ordinary maintenance. 
(b)  There is hereby imposed and levied by the city, subject to the provisions of Section 53.1-120 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended, an additional fee of ten dollars ($10.00) to be taxed as costs in each criminal or traffic case prosecuted on a city warrant or summons, in either the circuit court, general district court or the juvenile and domestic relations court. This additional assessment shall be used solely for the funding of courthouse security personnel, and, if requested by the sheriff, equipment, and other personal property used in connection with courthouse security. 
(Ord. of 6-26-90; Ord. of 6-12-06; Ord. of 6-23-09(2)) 
Sec. 4-2-17. - Exemptions for designated real property and designated personal property owned by certain nonprofit organizations. 
(a)  The city council may by designation exempt from taxation any real property or personal property owned by a nonprofit organization that uses such property solely for religious, charitable, patriotic, historical, benevolent, cultural, or public park or playground purposes. No exemption shall be granted to any organization except under the following conditions: 
(1)  The organization shall have no rule, regulation, policy or practice that unlawfully discriminates on the basis of religious conviction, race, color, sex or national origin; 
(2)  The organization must currently own the real estate or personal property in the city; 
(3)  The property for which the exemption is requested shall not be occupied or used by any person as a dwelling or for other personal use; and 
(4)  The exemptions shall only apply to the specific parcel(s) of land or specific item(s) of personal property for which the exemption is sought and not any property that may be acquired in the future by such organization. 
(b)  Any organization seeking a real property or personal property tax exemption under this section shall submit an application to the city manager for the specific parcel(s) of real property or for any personal property for which it seeks an exemption in accordance with an application form and written procedure developed by the city manager and the commissioner of the revenue. Applications shall be submitted on or before January 30 of any calendar year. Such application shall, at a minimum, include certifications, responses, and documentation, under oath, to the following questions: 
(1)  Does the organization have any rule, regulation, policy, or practice that unlawfully discriminates on the basis of religious conviction, race, color, sex or national origin? 
(2)  Is the organization exempt from taxation pursuant to Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954? 
(3)  Does the organization hold a current annual alcoholic beverage license from the Virginia Alcoholic Beverage Control Board for serving alcoholic beverages on such property? 
(4)  What compensation is paid to each director, officer, and employee of the organization and is such compensation in excess of a reasonable allowance for salary or other compensation for personal services which such director, officer or employee actually renders? 
(5)  Does any part of the net earnings of such organization inure to the benefit of any individual? 
(6)  What percentage of the services provided by such organization is generated by funds received from donations, contributions or local, state or federal grants or funds? For purposes of this subsection, donations shall include the providing of personal services or the contribution of in-kind or other material services. 
(7)  What specific services does the organization provide for the common good of the local citizens? 
(8)  What percentage of the activities of the organization involve carrying on propaganda or otherwise attempting to influence legislation? Does the organization participate or intervene in any political campaign on behalf of any candidate for public office? 
(9)  What is the amount of real property tax and/or personal property tax actually paid by the organization to the city for the preceding three (3) years on each parcel of real property or on each item of personal property for which the group seeks a tax exemption? 
(c)  Upon receipt of a complete application and receipt of an application fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), the city manager shall refer said application to a committee, consisting of the treasurer, commissioner of the revenue and the director of finance, to determine whether the applicant (i) meets the minimum requirements of this section, (ii) is in compliance with all city ordinances and regulations, and (iii) is not delinquent in the payment of any city taxes, fees, or other charges, and (iv) any other requirements as the committee may deem appropriate. Upon the completion of such review, the committee shall make a recommendation to the city council as to whether the exemption should be approved or rejected. The city manager shall include the request on the city council's agenda and shall cause a notice of a public hearing to be published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. The notice shall include the assessed value of the real property or personal property for which the exemption is requested as well as the property taxes assessed against such property. The public hearing shall not be held until at least five (5) days after the notice is published. The applicant shall, in addition to the application fee referred to above, pay the cost of the publication. 
(d)  The city council shall consider such application following the public hearing at which the public shall have an opportunity to be heard. The city council shall consider each of the questions set forth in subsection (b) above, as well as the recommendation of the committee, and any other criteria, facts, or circumstances that the city council deems pertinent, before adopting an ordinance granting the exemption. The ordinance shall state the specific use on which the exemption is based. Continuation of the exemption shall be contingent on the continued use of the property in accordance with the purpose for which the organization is designated. The effective date of any ordinance adopted under this section shall be July 1. 
(e)  Any real or personal property tax exemption granted pursuant to this section shall expire on March 1 following the third anniversary of the date on which the exemption was granted unless the organization has filed a form with the commissioner of the revenue certifying, under oath, that the organization and exempt property still meet the requirements of this section. If such organization fails to file such form by said date or otherwise fails to make proper certification, as determined by the commissioner of the revenue, such tax exemption shall expire. 
(f)  The commissioner of the revenue shall have the authority to request any relevant information, records, or other data from any charitable organization seeking a real estate tax or personal property tax exemption under this section or benefitting from any such exemption previously granted hereunder, to conduct audits of such organizations, and to take whatever measures he or she deems necessary and that are authorized by general law to ensure compliance with the purpose and intent of this section. 
(Ord. of 11-26-04; Ord. of 6-27-05) 
Sec. 4-2-18. - Community-based probation services agency; supervision and intervention fees. 
    Pursuant to authority granted in section 9.1-182 of the Code of Virginia (1950), as amended, and in acknowledgement that the County of Rockingham and the City of Harrisonburg have previously established a multi-jurisdictional Community Criminal Justice Board and operate a multi-jurisdictional Court Services Unit with Rockingham County acting as the fiscal agent, the Harrisonburg - Rockingham County Court Services Unit shall collect supervision and intervention fees from those parties, under the circumstances, and in the manner set forth in the following paragraphs. 
A.  For each separate incidence or occurrence of required supervision or intervention by the Harrisonburg - Rockingham County Court Services Unit, the locally supervised adult offender shall be charged a one-time supervision and intervention fee, which is a fee separate and distinct from the sentencing/supervision fee provided for elsewhere, of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for the first six (6) months of supervision or intervention, and an additional supervision and intervention fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for an additional six (6) months of supervision or intervention immediately following the first six months. Should additional months of supervision or intervention be required on the same incidence or occurrence, no additional supervision and intervention fees shall be collected. 
B.  Should the Harrisonburg - Rockingham County Court Services Unit send an adult offender to another community-based probation services agency, the Harrisonburg - Rockingham County Court Services Unit shall collect a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) supervision and intervention fee from the offender. Should the Harrisonburg - Rockingham County Court Services Unit receive an adult offender from another community-based probation services agency, the Harrisonburg - Rockingham County Court Services Unit shall collect from the offender a one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) supervision and intervention fee for the first six (6) months of supervision or intervention, and an additional twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be collected for an additional six (6) months of supervision or intervention immediately following the first six months. Should additional months of supervision or intervention be required on the same incidence or occurrence, no additional supervision and intervention fees shall be collected. 
C.  Where this article requires the Harrisonburg - Rockingham County Court Services Unit to collect a fee, the Harrisonburg - Rockingham County Court Services Unit shall send the offender to the Treasurer of Rockingham County for the actual payment. However, the Harrisonburg - Rockingham County Court Services Unit shall follow up with the offender in the event of non-payment. 
D.  Payment of fees required by this article shall be by cashiers check or money order. 
E.  A receipt for payment shall be provided by the Rockingham County Treasurer's office to the offender at the time of payment, and a copy shall be forwarded to the Harrisonburg - Rockingham County Court Services Unit for inclusion in the offender's file. 
F.  For good cause shown to the Harrisonburg - Rockingham County Court Services Unit, the payment of the first six-month fee may be paid in two (2) installments over a period of two (2) months. 
G.  The Rockingham County Treasurer shall maintain records of all moneys received pursuant to this ordinance, which records shall be audited annually. 
H.  Fees collected pursuant to this article shall be used solely for the expansion and development of the community-based probation services in Harrisonburg and Rockingham County, or to supplant local operating costs of that program. Fees may be used for components of the local program such as, but not limited to, community service, home incarceration with or without electronic monitoring, substance abuse assessment, testing and treatment, and other educational or treatment services required as conditions of probation. Fees collected pursuant to this ordinance shall not be used for indirect costs. 
(Ord. of 11-13-07) 
Sec. 4-2-19. - Assessment of costs in criminal and traffic cases for the costs of an electronic summons system. 
    There is hereby imposed and assessed by the city, subject to the provisions of  17.1-279.1 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended, an additional fee of five dollars ($5.00) as part of the costs in each criminal and traffic case prosecuted on a city warrant or summons, in either the circuit court, general district court, or juvenile and domestic relations district court. The clerk of the court in which the warrant or summons is filed shall collect these assessments and remit them to the city treasurer. The treasurer shall hold the funds subject to disbursements by the city council to the city police department solely to fund software, hardware, and associated equipment costs for the implementation and maintenance of an electronic summons system. 
( Ord. of 11-24-15(1), eff. 12-1-15 ) 
Sec. 4-2-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - REAL ESTATE TAX EXEMPTION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-2-21. - Exemption authorized. 
    A tax exemption for real estate and for mobile homes which are located on land owned by the applicant is provided for qualified property owners who are not less than sixty-five (65) years of age, or permanently and totally disabled, as defined in section 59-760.1, paragraph (3)(e) of the Code of Virginia, as amended to date, and who are eligible according to the terms of this chapter and section 58-760.1 of the 1950 Code of Virginia, as amended to date. Persons qualifying for exemption are deemed to be bearing an extraordinary real estate tax burden in relation to their income and financial worth. 
(Code 1973,  9-22.1; Ord. of 11-22-77; Ord. of 4-26-83) 
Sec. 4-2-22. - Administration. 
    The exemption shall be administered by the commissioner of the revenue according to the provisions of this chapter. The commissioner of the revenue is hereby authorized and empowered to prescribe, adopt, promulgate and enforce rules and regulations in conformity with the provisions of this chapter, including the requirement of answers under oath, as may be reasonably necessary to determine qualifications for exemption as specified by this chapter. The commissioner of the revenue may require the production of certified tax returns and appraisal reports to establish income or financial worth. The term "mobile home" as used in this ordinance shall mean a housing unit as defined in section 36-71(4) of the Code of Virginia of 1950, as amended. 
(Code 1973,  9-22.2; Ord. of 4-26-83) 
Sec. 4-2-23. - Requirements enumerated. 
    The exemption shall be granted, subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  The title to the property for which the exemption is claimed is held or partially held on July 1 of the taxable year by an eligible person claiming the exemption. 
(2)  The eligible person occupying the property as his or her sole dwelling and owning title, or partial title, thereto, is sixty-five (65) years old or older on December 31 of the year immediately preceding the taxable year, or is permanently and totally disabled, as defined in section 58-1-3217 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended. For the purposes of this section, "eligible person" means a person who is at least age 65 or permanently and totally disabled. Real property owned and occupied as the sole dwelling of an eligible person includes real property (i) held by the eligible person alone or in conjunction with his or her spouse as tenant or tenants for life or joint lives, (ii) held in a revocable inter vivos trust over which the eligible person or the eligible person and his or her spouse hold the power of revocation, or (iii) held in an irrevocable trust under which an eligible person alone or in conjunction with his or her spouse possesses a life estate or an estate for joint lives or enjoys a continuing right of use or support. The term "eligible person" does not include any interest held under a leasehold or term of years. 
(3)  The gross combined income of the owner or owners during the year immediately preceding the taxable year shall be determined by the commissioner of the revenue to be an amount not to exceed thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00). Gross combined income shall include all income from all sources of (i) the owners of the dwelling who use it as their sole residence, (ii) the owner's relatives living in the dwelling for which the exemption is claimed, except for those relatives living in the dwelling and providing bona fide caregiving services to the owner whether such relatives are compensated or not, and (iii) nonrelatives of the owner who live in the dwelling except for bona fide tenants or bona fide caregivers of the owner, whether compensated or not. Determination of gross combined income is further subject to subdivision 1b of section 58.1-3211 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended. 
(4)  The owner's net financial worth, including the present value of all equitable interest, as of December 31 of the immediately preceding calendar year, excluding the value of the principal residence and the land, not exceeding one (1) acre, upon which it is situated, shall not exceed seventy-five thousand dollars (75,000.00). 
(Code 1973,  9-22.3; Ord. of 1-22-77; Ord. of 1-22-80; Ord. of 4-27-82; Ord. of 5-14-85; Ord. of 11-26-91; Ord. of 12-15-98; Ord. of 6-14-05; Ord. of 6-10-08(1); Ord. of 11-11-14) 
Sec. 4-2-24. - Application for exemption. 
(a)  The person or persons filing for the exemption provided by this article B, shall file an application in the form of an affidavit setting forth (i) the names of the related persons occupying such real estate, (ii) the total combined net worth of the owners, including equitable interests, and (iii) the combined income from all sources of the persons specified in 4-2-23(2), which net worth and income must not exceed the limits established in this article. Such application shall be filed no later than May 1 immediately preceding the city's fiscal year for which exemption is desired, except in cases of a first time applicant or where the commissioner determines hardship, in which case application may be made up to June 30. 
(b)  The application referred to in subsection (a), immediately preceding, shall be filed at the time of the initial application and every three (3) years thereafter. If a person who, because of changed circumstances, loses the benefit of this exemption, wishes to reapply, he or she must proceed as if making an initial application. 
(c)  Annually, after qualification, by May 1, the exempt taxpayer shall file a certification with the commissioner, stating that no material circumstances have changed since the application or last annual certification. If material circumstances have changed, the taxpayer shall set forth the specifics. 
(d)  The commissioner shall prescribe forms for the application and annual certification referred to in this section. 
(e)  If, after audit and investigation, the commissioner determines that the taxpayer is qualified for exemption, he or she shall, prior to September 1 of each year, prepare and certify a list to the treasurer showing: name, address, parcel number, amount of real estate tax assessed, and amount of tax relief. 
(f)  The exemption granted by this article shall be revoked if the taxpayer fails to pay the reduced tax on time. The treasurer shall inform the commissioner and the director of finance of any revoked exemptions. 
(Code 1973,  9-22.4; Ord. of 12-15-98; Ord. of 1-13-04) 
Sec. 4-2-25. - Schedule of amounts. 
(a)  The person qualifying for the exemption shall be relieved of liability of the real estate tax levied on the qualifying dwelling and land in accordance with the following schedule: 
Combined Gross Income 
Exemption Percent Up to $15,000.00 80 $15,001.00 to $20,000.00 60 $20,001.00 to $25,000.00 40 $25,001.00 to $30,000.00 20  
(b)  The maximum tax relief grant for the current taxable year shall not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Code 1973,  9-22.25; Ord. of 1-22-80; Ord. of 4-27-82; Ord. of 5-14-85; Ord. of 11-26-91; Ord. of 6-14-05; Ord. of 6-10-08(1); Ord. of 6-10-08(2)) 
Sec. 4-2-26. - Violations of division 1. 
    Any person falsely or fraudulently claiming an exemption under this division 1, or providing false information to the commissioner, shall be guilty of a class one misdemeanor. Further, any person making false statements on an affidavit may be subject to prosecution for perjury. 
(Code 1973,  9-22.6; Ord. of 1-13-04) 
Sec. 4-2-27. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted Jan. 13, 2004, repealed  4-2-27, in its entirety. Former  4-2-27 pertained to incorporation of state code by reference and derived from Code 1973,  9-22.9 and an ordinance adopted Nov. 22, 1977. 
Sec. 4-2-28. - Partial exemption for certain rehabilitated, renovated or replacement residential and commercial structures. 
(a)  A partial exemption from taxation of commercial and residential real estate located within the B-1 Central Business District as defined in title 10, chapter 3, article O of the Harrisonburg City Code, no less than twenty-five (25) years of age, which has undergone substantial rehabilitation, renovation or replacement shall be allowed. 
(b)  The partial exemption from taxation of real estate which has been substantially rehabilitated by complete replacement shall only apply to replacement structures which can exceed the total square footage of the replaced structures used for commercial uses by no more than one hundred (100) percent and for residential uses by no more than thirty (30) percent. 
(c)  The partial exemption from taxation of real estate shall not exceed an amount equal to the increase in assessed value resulting from the rehabilitation, renovation or replacement of the commercial or residential structure as determined by the commissioner of the revenue. 
(d)  The partial exemption from taxation of real estate shall commence on July 1 of the year following completion of the rehabilitation, renovation or replacement and shall run with the real estate for a period of no longer than five (5) years. 
(e)  Nothing in this section shall be construed as to permit the commissioner of the revenue to list upon the land book any reduced value due to the exemption provided in subsection (c). 
(f)  The commissioner of the revenue shall assess a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for processing an application requesting the exemption provided by this section. No property shall be eligible for such exemption unless the appropriate building permits have been acquired and the commissioner of the revenue or assessing officer has verified that the rehabilitation, renovation or replacement indicated on the application has been completed. 
(g)  Where the rehabilitation is achieved through demolition and replacement of an existing structure, the exemption provided in subsection A shall not apply when any structure demolished is a registered Virginia landmark or is determined by the department of historic resources to contribute to the significance of a registered historic landmark. 
(Ord. of 8-8-95) 
Sec. 4-2-29. - Partial exemption for certain rehabilitated or renovated residential structures. 
(a)  A partial exemption from taxation of residential real estate located within the R-1 Single Family Residential District, R-2 Residential District and UR Urban Residential District, as defined in Title 10, Chapter 3, Articles H, I, and Z of the Harrisonburg City Code, shall be allowed pursuant to the terms and conditions set forth in the following subsections. 
(b)  To qualify for this partial exemption from real estate taxation, the owner of the real estate must show that (i) the structure on the property is no less than fifteen (15) years old, (ii) at the time of application the structure is, or within twelve (12) months prior to application was, legally in use as a multifamily residence or legally has, or within twelve (12) months of application had, more than two (2) unrelated tenants living in the structure, (iii) that the owner, within the twelve (12) months prior to application, has completed, or will undertake or is undertaking, substantial rehabilitation, renovation or conversion, to return the structure to single family use, (iv) the owner is using, or, as soon as the structure is habitable, will use, the structure as their primary residence and intends to continue to use the structure as their primary residence for at least five (5) years from the date of completion of renovation or rehabilitation, or they will rent the structure to a single family for single family use for that five-year period, or its remainder, or they will sell the structure with a deed restriction, made explicitly enforceable by the city, that the structure must be used as a single family residence for that five-year period, or its remainder. Making application shall be deemed an offer by the owner to waive and release any existing rights to maintain an preexisting nonconforming use, which waiver and release shall take effect upon the granting of the partial exemption from real estate taxes provided for in this section. 
(c)  Upon meeting all the terms and conditions of this section, the owner shall be granted a partial exemption from real estate taxes equal to either that portion of the tax resulting from an increase in assessed value as a result of the rehabilitations and renovations undertaken to return the property to single family use or twenty (20) percent of assessed value before rehabilitation, whichever is greater. The exemption shall remain in force for a period of seven (7) years from the effective date of the first reassessment after completion of the conversion. If, at any time during the seven (7) years of the exemption, the property is used for any purpose other than single family residence, the exemption shall immediately cease and the entire amount of tax exemption granted up to that time shall be recovered from the then current owner. Such recovery, or rollback, shall be billed with the next regular real estate tax bill, and shall be collected as other real estate taxes. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to permit the commissioner of the revenue to list upon the land book any reduced value due to the exemption provided in this section. 
(e)  The commissioner of the revenue shall assess of fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for processing an application requesting the exemption provided by this section. No property shall be eligible for such exemption unless all appropriate building permits have been acquired and the commissioner of the revenue or the assessing officer has verified that the rehabilitation, renovation or conversion indicated in the application has been completed. 
(Ord. of 5-27-03) 
Sec. 4-2-30. - Partial exemption for new construction in the economic revitalization zone. 
(a)  A partial exemption from taxation of commercial and residential real estate located within the city's economic revitalization zone, as defined below, for all new construction shall be allowed. 
(b)  The city's economic revitalization zone is defined as being all parcels of real estate located within the city's B-1 business zone and the city's Virginia Main Street district as they exist on the effective date of this section. 
(c)  The partial exemption from taxation shall only apply to new construction with a minimum investment of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00), excluding the value of the real estate and at least forty (40) per cent of the first floor or street level square footage shall be used for retail sales and/or restaurant use. Exceptions to the square footage requirement set forth above can only be granted by the city council. 
(d)  The partial exemption from taxation shall not exceed the difference between the assessed value of the real estate following the completion and issuance of an occupancy permit for the new construction and the assessed value of the real estate immediately prior to the issuance of the building permit for the new construction. 
(e)  The partial exemption from taxation of real estate shall commence on July 1 of the year following the completion and issuance of an occupancy permit for the new construction and shall run with the real estate for the following periods and based on the amount invested in the new construction: 
$1,000,000.00 to $9,999,999,99 5 years $10,000,000.00 to $19,999,999.99 8 years $20,000,000.00 and above 10 years  
(f)  The commissioner of the revenue shall assess a fee of one hundred ($100.00) dollars for processing an application requesting the exemption provided by this section. No property shall be eligible for such exemption unless the appropriate building permits have been acquired and the commissioner of the revenue or assessing officer has verified that the new construction indicated on the application has been completed and the certificate of occupancy has been issued. 
(g)  Nothing in this section shall be construed as to permit the commissioner of the revenue to list upon the land book any reduced value due to the exemption provided in subsection (d). 
(h)  Where the new construction is achieved through demolition or replacement of an existing structure, the exemption provided by this section shall not apply when any structure demolished is a registered Virginia landmark or is determined by the department of historic resources to contribute to the significance of a registered historic landmark. 
(Ord. of 12-11-07) 
Sec. 4-2-31. - Exemption for properties using certified solar equipment, facilities or devices. 
(a)  Effective on and after July 1, 2010, for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2010 and ending June 30, 2011 and for each fiscal year thereafter, unless otherwise changed by the city council, certified solar equipment, facilities or devices, as defined herein, are hereby declared to be a separate class of property and shall be exempt from taxation at one hundred (100) percent of its assessed value for the first twenty (20) years of its useful life. 
(b)  As used in this section: 
(1)  "Certified solar equipment, facilities or devices" means any property, including real or personal property, equipment, facilities or devices certified by the city's building inspections division to be designed and used primarily for the purpose of providing for the collection and use of incident solar energy for water heating, space heating or cooling, or other application which would otherwise require a conventional source of energy such as petroleum products, natural gas or electricity. 
(2)  "Local certifying authority" means the city's building inspections division of the city's department of community development. 
(c)  Any person residing in the city may proceed to have solar energy equipment, facilities or devices certified as exempt from taxation by applying to the city's building inspections division. If, after examination of such equipment, facility or device, the building inspections division determines that the unit primarily performs any of the functions set forth in subsection (b) of this section and conforms to the requirements set by the state board of housing and community development, the building inspections division shall approve and certify such application. The building inspections division shall forthwith transmit to the commissioner of the revenue those applications properly approved and certified by the building inspections division as meeting all of the requirements qualifying such equipment, facility or device for the exemption from taxation. Any person aggrieved by a decision by the building inspections division may appeal such decision to the local board of building code appeals, which may affirm or reverse such decision. 
(d)  Upon receipt of the certificate from the city's building inspections division, the commissioner of the revenue shall proceed to determine the value of such qualifying solar energy equipment, facilities or devices. The exemption provided by this section shall be determined by applying the local tax rate to the value of such equipment, facilities or devices and subtracting such partially exempt amount, either: (i) from the total real property tax due on the real property to which such equipment, facilities or devices are attached or (ii) if such, equipment, facilities, or devices are taxable as machinery and tools from the total machinery and tools due on such equipment, facilities, or devices, at the election of the taxpayer. This exemption shall be effective beginning in the next succeeding tax year after the date of approval by the commissioner of the revenue, and shall remain in effect for the nineteen (19) following tax years. In the event the qualifying equipment, facilities or devices is part of a new building subject to assessment, then the exemption shall be first effective when such real estate is first assessed, but not prior to the date of such application for exemption. 
(e)  It shall be presumed for the purpose of the administration of this section, and for no other purposes, that the value of such qualifying solar energy equipment, facilities and devices is not less than the normal cost of purchasing and installing such equipment, facilities and devices. 
(Ord. of 3-22-11(1)) 
Sec. 4-2-32. - Partial exemption for new construction in the retail revitalization zone. 
(a)  A partial exemption from taxation of commercial and residential real estate located within the city's retail revitalization zone, as defined below, for all new construction and/or redevelopment shall be allowed. 
(b)  The city's retail revitalization zone is defined as being all parcels of real estate located within the following boundaries: 
South Main Street retail revitalization zone -Beginning at the southern city limit and its intersection with Interstate 81; thence following the northwestern side of Interstate 81 to its intersection with the Norfolk Western railroad track; thence following the western side of the Norfolk Western railroad track to the intersection with South Main Street; thence following South Main Street to the intersection with South Avenue; thence following South Main Street to Baxter Drive; thence following Baxter Drive to the western city limit; thence following the western city limit to the southern city limit; thence along the southern city limit to the beginning. In addition, all properties that adjoin South Main Street between South Avenue and the southern city limit are also included in this zone. 
East Market Street retail revitalization zone -Beginning at the intersection of Interstate 81 with Reservoir Street; thence following the eastern side of Reservoir Street to its intersection with Lucy Drive; thence following the northern side of Lucy Drive to its intersection with Evelyn Byrd Avenue; thence following the northern side of Evelyn Byrd Avenue to its intersection with East Market Street; thence along the southern side of East Market Street to its intersection with Country Club Road; thence along the southern side of Country Club Road to its intersection with Interstate 81; thence along the eastern side of Interstate 81 to the beginning. In addition, all properties that adjoin East Market Street and are located east of Evelyn Byrd Avenue and west of the eastern city limit are also included in this zone. 
(c)  The partial exemption from taxation shall only apply to new construction and/or redevelopment that results in an increased assessed value of at least one million dollars ($1,000,000.00). In addition, at least seventy-five (75) percent of the total square footage shall be used for retail sales and/or restaurant use. Exceptions to the square footage requirement set forth above can only be granted by Harrisonburg City Council. 
(d)  The partial exemption from taxation shall not exceed the difference between the assessed value of the real estate following the completion and issuance of an occupancy permit for the new construction and/or redevelopment and the assessed value of the real estate immediately prior to the issuance of the building permit for the new construction and/or redevelopment. 
(e)  The partial exemption from taxation of real estate shall commence on July 1 of the year following the completion and issuance of the occupancy permit for construction and shall run with the real estate for the following periods and based on the amount invested in the project: 
$1,000,000.00 to $9,999,999.99 5 years $10,000,000.00 to $19,999,999.99 8 years $20,000,000.00 and above 10 years  
(f)  Qualified retail businesses shall be exempted from payment of fifty (50) percent of the business, professional and occupational license taxes and fees imposed by chapter 1 of title 12 of the Harrisonburg City Code for the first one (1) full calendar year following actual occupation by the qualified retail business within the retail revitalization zone. 
(g)  Definition: Qualified retail business. The term "qualified retail business" shall mean a business entity that (1) has been designated as a retail operation by the Harrisonburg Commissioner of the Revenue for the purpose of reporting and paying business, professional and occupational license (BPOL) tax and fees to the City of Harrisonburg, and (2) has been issued an occupancy permit within a facility that meets the requirements to qualify for the retail revitalization zone real estate partial tax exemption as described in subsection (e) above. Existing retailers doing business within the City of Harrisonburg shall not be eligible for this partial BPOL exemption by relocating to a facility within the retail revitalization zone boundaries. 
(h)  The Harrisonburg Commissioner of the Revenue shall assess a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for processing an application requesting the exemption provided by this section. No property shall be eligible for such exemption unless the appropriate building permits have been acquired and the commissioner of the revenue or assessing officer has verified that the new construction indicated on the application has been completed and the certificate of occupancy has been issued. 
    Investments made by an applicant within a thirty-six (36) month period from the date of the original application shall be totaled and applied to the exemption time periods detailed in subsection (e) above. 
    Once this thirty-six (36) month period ends from the date of the original application and the exemption time period is established, the applicant is ineligible to re-apply for this program until the appropriate exemption time period has expired. 
(i)  Nothing in this section shall be construed as to permit the Harrisonburg Commissioner of Revenue to list upon the city land book any reduced value due to the exemption provided in subsection (e). 
(j)  Where the new construction is achieved through demolition or replacement of an existing structure, the exemption provided by this section shall not apply when any structure demolished is a registered Virginia landmark or is determined by the Virginia Department of Historic Resources to contribute to the significance of a registered historic landmark. 
(Ord. of 6-26-12(4); Ord. of 2-10-15 ) 
Editor's note- Ord. of 6-26-12(4), set out provisions intended for use as  4-2-31. At the editor's discretion, to prevent duplication of section numbers, these provisions have been included as  4-2-32. 
Secs. 4-2-33-4-2-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SERVICE CHARGE ON EXEMPTED PROPERTY 

Sec. 4-2-41. - Service charge imposed. 
(a)  A fee or service charge shall be applicable to the real estate for which the city furnished police and fire protection where such real estate is exempt from taxes under the provisions of section 58-12 of the Code of Virginia and shall be collected from the owner or the party in possession of such real estate. 
(b)  Such service charge shall be fixed by dividing the budget expenditures for such services by the assessed fair market value of all of the real estate within the city, including nontaxable property, except real estate owned by the federal government, which assessed fair market value shall be expressed in increments of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
Sec. 4-2-42. - Rate. 
    The annual rate of the service charge imposed by the city council as a part of the annual budget ordinance for property subject to such charge under section 4-2-41 for which the city furnishes police and fire protection shall not be in excess of the maximum rate as specified in section 58-16.2 of the Code of Virginia as amended to date. 
Sec. 4-2-43. - Payments. 
    The annual service charges imposed under sections 4-2-41 and 4-2-42 shall be due and payable on December 5, 1979, and on each December fifth thereafter. 
Sec. 4-2-44. - Exemptions. 
    The buildings, with the land that such buildings actually occupy, lawfully owned and held by churches or religious bodies and which are wholly and exclusively used for religious worship, or for the residence of the minister of any such church or religious body as well as the additional adjoining land reasonably necessary for the convenient use of such buildings and public burial grounds or cemeteries not operated for profit shall be exempt from the service charge imposed under this division for police and fire protection. 
Secs. 4-2-45-4-2-50. - Reserved.

ARTICLE D. - UTILITY TAX 

Sec. 4-2-61. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Commercial or industrial user: The owner or tenant of property used for commercial or industrial purposes, including apartment buildings, who pays for utility service for such property. 
    Purchaser: Every person who purchases a utility service. 
    Residential user: The owner or tenant of private residential property who pays for utility service in or for such property. 
    Seller: Every person who sells or furnishes a utility service. 
    Utility services: Local exchange telephone service, electrical service, gas service and water service furnished within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1973,  9-26) 
Sec. 4-2-62. - Levy of tax; amount. 
(a)  Except as hereinafter provided, there is hereby imposed and levied by the city upon each and every purchaser of a utility service a tax in the amount of twenty (20) percentum of the charge (exclusive of any federal tax thereon) made by the seller against the purchaser with respect to each utility service, which tax in every case shall be collected by the seller from the purchaser and shall be paid by the purchaser to the seller for the use of the city at the time the purchase price or such charge shall become due and payable under the agreement between the purchaser and the seller; provided, that in case any monthly bill submitted by any seller for residential service shall exceed ten dollars ($10.00) for a residential user, there shall be no tax computed on so much of such bill as shall exceed ten dollars ($10.00) and in case any monthly bill submitted by any seller for commercial or industrial service shall exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) there shall be no tax computed on so much of such bill as shall exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00). Bills shall be considered monthly bills if submitted twelve (12) times per year for periods of approximately one (1) month each. In case bills are submitted by any seller for two (2) months' service, there shall be no tax computed on so much of such bill as shall exceed twenty dollars ($20.00) for a residential user or two hundred dollars ($200.00) for a commercial or industrial user. 
(b)  Effective with the first bill for electric energy rendered for meter readings on or after July 1, 2017, the rate of tax on the electric energy delivered to the user shall be as follows: 
(1)  Residential user: Each residential user shall pay a base tax rate of one dollar ($1.00) per month, plus $0.0024 per kilowatt hour (kWh) delivered, with a maximum tax of two dollars ($2.00) per month. 
(2)  Commercial or industrial user: Each commercial or industrial user shall pay a base tax rate of one dollar ($1.00) per month, plus $0.0166 per kilowatt hour (kWh) delivered, with a maximum tax of twenty dollars ($20.00) per month. 
(c)  Effective with the first bill for gas service rendered for meter readings on or after July 1, 2017, the rate of tax on the natural gas delivered to the user shall be as follows: 
(1)  Residential user: Each residential user shall pay a flat tax of two dollars ($2.00) per individual or separate residence per month. 
(2)  Commercial or industrial user: Each commercial or industrial user shall pay a base tax rate of four dollars and sixty-five cents ($4.65) per month, plus $0.155 per one hundred (100) cubic feet of gas at standard pressure and temperature (CCF) delivered, with a maximum tax of twenty dollars ($20.00) per month. 
(Code 1973,  9-27; Ord. of 10-26-00; Ord. of 3-13-01; Ord. of 5-9-17(1), eff. 7-1-17) 
Sec. 4-2-63. - Duty of seller to collect tax; reports to commissioner of revenue; remittances to treasurer. 
    It shall be the duty of every seller in acting as the tax-collecting medium or agency for the city to collect from the purchaser for the use of the city the tax hereby imposed and levied at the time of collecting the purchase price charged, and the taxes collected during each calendar month shall be reported by each seller to the commissioner of the revenue and each seller shall remit the amount of tax shown by such report to have been collected to the city treasurer on or before the last day of the first calendar month thereafter, together with the name and address of any purchaser who has refused to pay his tax. The required reports shall be in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the revenue. 
(Code 1973,  9-28) 
Sec. 4-2-64. - Records to be kept by seller. 
    Each and every seller shall keep complete records showing all purchases in the city, which records shall show the price charged against each purchaser with respect to each purchase, the date thereof, and the date of payments thereof, and the amount of tax imposed hereunder, and such record shall be kept open for inspection by the duly authorized agents of the city at reasonable times, and the duly authorized agents of the city shall have the right, power and authority to make transcripts thereof. 
(Code 1973,  9-29) 
Sec. 4-2-65. - Exemptions. 
    The United States of America, the state and the political subdivisions, boards, commissions and authorities thereof are hereby exempted from the payment of the tax imposed and levied by this article with respect to the purchase of utility services used by such governmental agencies. 
(Code 1973,  9-30) 
Sec. 4-2-66. - Telephone service. 
    The tax hereby imposed and levied on purchasers with respect to local exchange telephone service shall apply to all charges made for local exchange telephone service, except local messages which are paid for by inserting coins in coin-operated telephones. 
    In order to finance and establish the E-911 Emergency Services System, in addition to the other tax established by this section and in compliance with the terms of section 58-3813 of the Code of Virginia, as amended to date, there shall be added to the bill for each telephone access line in the city a monthly fee for the purpose of paying the cost of installation of said system and after said installation is completed, a fee for the maintenance cost of said system. 
    The amount of said fees shall be established by council. 
    The local telephone company shall collect the monthly fees established by council and pay these amounts to the city. The city shall then pay from the revenues thus collected its share as determined by the number of access lines which are a part of the E-911 system in the city. 
(Code 1973,  9-31; Ord. of 4-22-86) 
Sec. 4-2-66.1. - Mobile local telecommunication service tax. 
(a)  As used in this section, unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    Mobile local telecommunication service means any two-way mobile or portable local telecommunication service, including cellular mobile radio telecommunication service and specialized mobile radio.
