The assessment of the penalty shall not be deemed a defense to any criminal prosecution for failing to make any return or remittance as required in this article. Additionally, interest on late tax payments shall accrue at the rate of ten (10) percent per year. Penalty and interest for failure to pay the tax assessed pursuant to this article shall be assessed on the first day following the day such quarterly installment payment is due. 
(Ord. of 11-24-09(2)) 
Sec. 4-2-136. - Exclusions and exemptions. 
    No short-term rental tax shall be collected or assessed on rentals by the commonwealth, any political subdivision of the commonwealth or the United States. Additionally, all exemptions applicable in Title 58.1, Chapter 6 (Section 58.1-600 et seq.) of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended, shall apply mutatis mutandis to the short-term rental tax, except that the commissioner of the revenue shall assess the tax due, and the treasurer shall collect the short-term rental property tax, instead of the department of taxation. 
(Ord. of 11-24-09(2)) 
Sec. 4-2-137. - Certificate of registration. 
(a)  Every person engaging in the short-term rental business shall annually file an application for a certificate of registration with the commissioner of the revenue. Such application shall be filed no later than January 31st of each year. The application shall be on a form prescribed by the commissioner of the revenue and shall set forth the name under which the applicant intends to operate the rental business, the location of the rental business and such other information as the commissioner of the revenue may require. 
(b)  An application must be signed by the owner or owners of the rental business. If the rental business is owned by an association, partnership or corporation, the application must be signed by a member, partner, executive officer or other person specifically authorized by the association, partnership or corporation to sign on its behalf. 
(c)  Upon the commissioner of the revenue's approval of the application the commissioner of the revenue shall issue a certificate of registration. The certificate shall be conspicuously displayed at all times at the place of business for which it is issued. 
(d)  The certificate is not assignable and shall be valid only for the person in whose name it is issued and the place of business designated. 
(Ord. of 11-24-09(2)) 
Sec. 4-2-138. - Criminal penalties for violation of article. 
    Any person violating or failing to comply with any provision of this article shall be guilty of a Class 3 misdemeanor. However, if the amount of tax due for any quarter exceeds one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), any person failing to remit such tax when due or failing to file a return for such quarter shall be guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. of 11-24-09(2)) 
CHAPTER 3. - PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING[7] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note- An ordinance of Feb. 8, 1983, amended Ch. 3 of Title 4 to read as herein set out, at the discretion of the editor, in  4-3-1. Prior to amendment, Ch. 3 of Title 4,  4-3-1-4-3-3, relative to purchasing and contracting, derived from Code 1973,  2-1 and 2-128. 

Sec. 4-3-1. - Manual adopted. 
    The purchasing and contracting policy manual which was approved by first reading of an ordinance January 25, 1983, in open session of this council, is hereby adopted in its entirety and incorporated by reference as a part of this chapter. The purchasing and contracting policy manual may be amended from time to time as council deems necessary and proper, by resolution, said amendments being adopted hereby as a part of this chapter upon the approval by council. 
(Ord. of 2-8-83) 
CHAPTER 4. - SINKING FUND COMMISSION[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Charter reference- Sinking fund commission,  52. 

Sec. 4-4-1. - Composition; election of chairman; secretary; quorum. 
    The sinking fund commission shall be composed of the city treasurer, the director of finance and one member of the council, the latter of whom shall be appointed by the council. The commission shall elect one of its members as chairman, who shall serve until his successor is elected and has qualified. The director of finance shall be the secretary of the commission. It shall be the duty of the secretary to record in the minute book of the commission the actions of the commission and to preserve all books, papers and records of the commission in his office. A quorum at any meeting of the commission shall consist of two (2) of its members. 
(Code 1973,  2-164; Ord. of 4-4-1) 
Sec. 4-4-2. - Duties generally. 
    The duties of the sinking fund commission shall be the management, preservation and application of the sinking fund required to be created by the charter and ordinances. 
(Code 1973,  2-165) 
Sec. 4-4-3. - Custodian of money, bonds, etc.; deposit of investments. 
    The city treasurer shall be the custodian of all money, bonds and other evidence of debt belonging to the sinking fund commission. All investments purchased by the sinking fund commission shall be deposited with and placed by the city treasurer in a safety deposit box in the vault of a bank approved by the sinking fund commission. 
(Code 1973,  2-166) 
Sec. 4-4-4. - Secretary to report on meetings. 
    The secretary of the sinking fund commission, in addition to the duties assigned to him under the provisions of section 4-4-1, shall file, at the next regular meeting of the council following each meeting of the sinking fund commission, a written report setting forth the actions of the sinking fund commission at such meeting. 
(Code 1973,  2-167) 
Sec. 4-4-5. - Opening of safety deposit box. 
    The bank safety deposit box of the sinking fund commission shall be opened only in the presence of the city treasurer, or his deputy in the absence of the city treasurer. 
(Code 1973,  2-168) 
Sec. 4-4-6. - Revenues to be set apart; designation of sinking fund. 
    The council shall set apart from the resources of the city such amounts of its revenues as it deems advisable to be applied to the payment of such specific bonded indebtedness of the city as it may determine, pursuant to the requirements of the Charter, ordinances and resolutions of the city. Such funds shall be set apart at such time and in such amounts as the sinking fund commission may direct, which funds shall be placed to the credit of the sinking fund account of the city. The funds thus set apart and invested, together with the interest and profits therefrom, shall be designated as the sinking fund, and shall be kept for and are hereby dedicated to the payment of the specific bonded indebtedness of the city for which they were set apart, and shall not be applied to or for any other purpose. 
(Code 1973,  2-169) 
Sec. 4-4-7. - Purchase or retirement of specific bonded indebtedness of city. 
    The sinking fund commission shall apply all appropriations and all interest and profits from any bonds or investments held in the sinking fund for the purchase or retirement of the specific bonded indebtedness of the city, the payment of which was contemplated by the ordinance or resolution providing therefor, including interest and handling charges. The accrued interest on such securities shall be collected by the city treasurer when due, and deposited to the credit of the sinking fund. All such securities shall be held and the interest thereon reinvested according to the provisions of this article, until some part of the principal or interest of the specific bonded indebtedness of the city for which it was set apart shall become due, when, unless other provisions be made by the council, such securities, so far as may be necessary, shall be sold and the proceeds applied to the payment of such matured part of the city's indebtedness. 
(Code 1973,  2-170) 
Sec. 4-4-8. - Disbursements of sinking fund. 
    All disbursements of the city sinking fund shall be made by check issued in accordance with the provisions of this code and with the authority of the council. 
(Code 1973,  2-171) 
CHAPTER 5. - CITY INSURANCE 

Sec. 4-5-1. - Eligibility of agents. 
    In order for an agency to be eligible to share in the writing of insurance or surety bonds for the city, or to share in the distribution of commissions earned, the agency must reside in and have its principal office in the city, have been in business in the city for at least five (5) years and intend to continue in business in the city on a permanent basis, and must be an independent agency owning its renewals in its principal company, or companies and must not be contractually obligated to represent only one (1) company. Eligible agencies shall be construed to mean those whose principal business is the writing of fire, casualty and surety insurance. 
(Code 1973,  2-137) 
Sec. 4-5-2. - Method of distribution. 
    The following provisions relative to the distribution of the city's insurance business shall hereafter be in effect and be complied with: 
(1)  The city's insurance business shall be placed with policy writing resident insurance agencies or brokers residing and having offices within the city, whose principal business is that of writing fire, casualty and surety insurance. 
(2)  The city council shall, from the agencies eligible to participate in the city's insurance business, as defined in the foregoing section, designate one (1) agency or broker to write the city's fire insurance schedule, one (1) agency or broker to write the city's casualty insurance schedule and one (1) agency or broker to write the city's surety or bond schedule, none of which agencies or brokers shall be designated to write more than one (1) of such schedules at the same time. 
(3)  The three (3) agencies or brokers so designated by the council to write the fire, casualty and surety lines of the city's insurance business, hereinafter referred to as the "agency of record" or the "broker of record," shall each receive 27-1/2) per centum of the commissions arising from the respective line of insurance written by him, and the remaining 72-1/2 per centum of such commissions shall be distributed by such broker of record among all agencies qualifying for participation under section 4-5-1 of this chapter, each of whom shall receive an equal share of such remaining commissions; provided, that such distributions shall be made at the end of the year, with appropriate adjustments as to agencies becoming eligible or ineligible for participation during the year. 
(4)  Upon the renewal date of the policies under each line of insurance, each agent eligible to serve as broker of record may submit bids for any of the lines of insurance then being purchased by the city and the city shall renew that line of insurance with the agent submitting the lowest acceptable bid. 
(Code 1973,  2-138) 
Sec. 4-5-3. - Duties of brokers of record. 
    In addition to the foregoing, the brokers of record designated by the council shall: 
(1)  Cause as few policies to be written in their respective lines as is dictated by good insurance practice. 
(2)  Cause policies to be written for such period or term as to such broker may seem to be to the best interests of the city. 
(3)  Keep the city manager informed concerning the insurance needs of the city, any rebates to which the city may become entitled, any change in rates which may materially affect the city, and, in general, to counsel and advise the city, through the city manager, respecting the city's insurance program in each of their respective lines of insurance. 
(4)  The fire insurance broker of record is hereby charged with the further duty and responsibility of negotiating with the rating bureau concerning rates and forms, and supervising the preparation of all forms and inspecting all policies written in connection with the fire insurance schedule. 
(Code 1973,  2-139) 
Title 5 - PUBLIC SAFETY 
CHAPTER 1. - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Police and public order, Va. Code, Title 15.1, Ch. 3; authority of cities to preserve peace, Va. Code,  15.1-137; powers and duties of police force, Va. Code,  15.1-138. 

ARTICLE A. - POLICE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 5-1-1. - Composition. 
    The police department of the city shall consist of the chief of police and such number of assistant chiefs, captains, lieutenants, sergeants, patrolmen, special policemen or other employees, by whatever rank they may be designated, as the council, on the recommendation of the city manager, may prescribe. 
(Code 1973,  21-1) 
Sec. 5-1-2. - Appointment of employees and members other than chief of police. 
(a)  The chief of police shall, with the approval of the city manager, appoint the assistant chiefs, captains, lieutenants, sergeants, patrolmen and all other employees, except special policemen, as may be deemed necessary to carry on the work of the police department. 
(b)  The chief of police shall avail himself as far as is reasonably possible of accepted personnel practices in making any and all appointments to the police department, including written applications, adaptability tests or other written or oral examinations, physical examinations, character investigations and personal interviews. 
(Code 1973,  21-2) 
Sec. 5-1-3. - Special officer and parking enforcement officers. 
    All special officers and parking enforcement officers shall be appointed by the chief of police as needed, with the approval of the city manager. The term of the special officer and parking enforcement officer so appointed shall be at the pleasure of the chief of police, with approval of the city manager. 
(Code 1973,  21-3; Ord. of 6-28-94) 
Sec. 5-1-4. - Qualifications of police officers. 
(a)  No person shall be appointed an officer of the police department below the rank of chief who is less than twenty-one (21) years of age at the time of appointment. 
(b)  All applicants for such positions must at the time of appointment be and remain during the term of office of good moral standing and physical condition and be able to read intelligently and to write legibly. 
Sec. 5-1-5. - Rules and regulations. 
    All members of the police force must acquire and possess full knowledge of the rules and regulations provided by the city manager relative to the police department in connection with their powers and duties and must act accordingly and be bound thereby. 
(Code 1973,  21-5) 
Sec. 5-1-6. - Obedience to chief of police. 
    It shall be the duty of the members of the police department to respect and obey all orders of the chief of police. 
(Code 1973,  21-6) 
Sec. 5-1-7. - Deportment while on duty. 
    Police officers must be quiet, civil, courteous and orderly in their deportment and conduct and must at all times refrain from violence or profane language, and in the performance of their duty must maintain full command of their tempers. When on a tour of service, police officers must not, except when on duty together, walk or talk with each other or with any other person whom they meet on any part of their beat, unless it be to receive or communicate information pertaining to their duties, or to answer civilly but briefly questions of strangers or citizens really requiring assistance or direction. They must not under any circumstances, unless in the discharge of their duties, enter any house, sit down, stop at corners of streets for a longer period than ten (10) minutes or in any manner linger along their routes, but shall constantly patrol their beats. 
(Code 1973,  21-8) 
Sec. 5-1-8. - Description of convict. 
    No person convicted of violating any ordinance of the city shall, upon request of the chief of police, fail to give to the police department a description of himself. This description shall include his name, age and height and shall be kept on file in the police department. 
(Code 1973,  21-9) 
Sec. 5-1-9. - Fingerprints of convict. 
    Any person convicted of violating any ordinance of the city who refuses to permit the police department to take his fingerprints shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973,  21-10) 
Sec. 5-1-10. - Fingerprinting for concealed handgun permits. 
    Any resident of the city applying for a concealed handgun permit pursuant to  18.2-308 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended, shall be required to comply with all provisions of that section. In order to determine the applicant's suitability for a concealed handgun permit, the applicant shall be fingerprinted by the city police department. The fingerprints and descriptive information shall be forwarded through the Virginia State Police to the FBI for a national criminal history record check. Once the fingerprints are returned by the Virginia State Police the city police department shall comply with  18.2-308(D) of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended, in notifying the applicant and disposing of the fingerprint cards. 
(Ord. of 6-10-97) 
Sec. 5-1-11. - Employment of off-duty law enforcement officers. 
    City law enforcement officers are authorized to engage in off-duty employment by private employers which may occasionally require the use of their police powers in the performance of such employment; provided, that such off-duty employment conform with the reasonable rules and regulations promulgated by the chief of police. 
(Ord. of 4-10-18) 
Secs. 5-1-12-5-1-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE B. - CHIEF OF POLICE 

Sec. 5-1-21. - Appointment; term. 
    The city manager shall appoint a chief of police, whose term of office shall be at the pleasure of the city manager. 
(Code 1973,  21-11) 
Sec. 5-1-22. - Powers and duties generally. 
(a)  The chief of police shall be the chief active executive of the police department and he shall be subject to the orders of the city manager. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the chief of police, at all times, day or night, to preserve the public peace, prevent the commission of crime, arrest offenders, to protect the rights of persons and of property, to regard the public health, to report nuisances in the streets, alleys and other places, to provide proper police force at fires and to protect firemen and property thereat. 
(c)  The chief of police shall see that all members of the police department subordinate to him, are at all times polite and respectful to all persons seeking information from them and shall see that in the performance of their duties they are always as courteous and gentlemanly as the situation requires and that there is no unnecessary display or use of firearms or other weapons, or parade of authority. 
(Code 1973,  21-12) 
Sec. 5-1-23. - Provision of information to department heads. 
    The chief of police shall transmit to the heads of the departments of the city government any information coming to the chief respecting street conditions, health conditions, defects in the water or sewer lines, or in the electric light system, or of any person needing charity assistance, or any other matter of general information pertaining to the city's welfare or business. 
(Code 1973,  21-14) 
Sec. 5-1-24. - Record of arrest and offenses. 
    The chief of police shall keep in his office subject to inspection at all times by the mayor, members of the council and city manager such books and records as are necessary in order to show the following: total number of arrests made; the offense charged; the disposition of the case; the fine and costs imposed, and the portion thereof collected; the name of the officer making the arrest; and any other books or papers necessary in order to preserve in detail a complete history of the transactions handled by the police department. 
(Code 1973,  21-16) 
Sec. 5-1-25. - Collection and disposition of fines, costs and parking meter funds. 
    The chief of police shall regularly collect from the city parking meters all deposits made therein and pay such collections and such other collections which he may make to the city treasurer, at times prescribed by the city treasurer, and for which the treasurer shall issue a receipt to the chief. 
Sec. 5-1-26. - Additional duties. 
    The chief of police shall perform such additional duties other than those imposed upon him by this chapter as may be required of him by the council or city manager. 
Sec. 5-1-27. - Absence or sickness. 
    The chief of police shall not leave the city unless he shall first receive permission to do so from the city manager. When such permission is granted, or in case of sickness, the chief shall designate an officer as acting chief of police during his absence. This rule shall not apply when it may become necessary to leave the city hurriedly on business directly connected with the police department. 
(Code 1973,  21-19) 
Sec. 5-1-28. - Suspension or removal of officers. 
(a)  Members of the police department shall be subject to suspension or removal at the discretion of the chief of police for neglect of duty, inefficiency, conduct unbecoming an officer or other cause. Charges in writing may be brought against an officer by any citizen. In which case the charges shall be carefully investigated by the chief of police, and opportunity provided for the complainant and the officer charged to be heard. 
(b)  All suspensions and removals shall be reported by the chief of police to the city manager. 
(Code 1973,  21-20) 
CHAPTER 2. - FIRE PROTECTION AND PREVENTION[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Fire protection generally, Va. Code, Title 27; authority of city to regulate for purpose of fire protection, Va. Code,  15.1-15(4). 

ARTICLE A. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 5-2-1. - Fire prevention code adopted. 
(a)  The Virginia Statewide Fire Prevention Code, as adopted by the Virginia Department of Housing and Community Development, pursuant to  27-97 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended, is hereby adopted and made a part of the Code of the City of Harrisonburg. The fire chief shall be responsible for the enforcement of the fire prevention code and, in addition, shall have the duty and responsibility to review the plans of all new developments within the city and require the installation of water lines and fire hydrants when necessary for adequate fire protection. All future amendments to the above referenced Code as enacted after the effective date of this article, are adopted and made a part of this section as fully as though set out herein and are hereby made applicable within the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with the provisions of the Virginia Statewide Fire Prevention Code herein adopted and any person found in violation shall be guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. of 5-14-85; Ord. of 5-10-88; Ord. of 6-27-89; Ord. of 9-9-97; Ord. of 3-23-04; Ord. of 12-13-05; Ord. of 9-8-09(2)) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to adopt fire prevention code by reference, Va. Code,  27-5.1. 
Sec. 5-2-2. - Permits and licenses. 
(a)  Any permits or licenses referenced in the fire prevention code that are issued in the city, shall be issued by the fire chief. 
(b)  Fees for various permits and licenses shall be as propagated from time to time by the fire chief. 
(Ord. of 7-11-78; Ord. of 3-23-04) 
Sec. 5-2-3. - Obstructions within fifteen feet of fire hydrant. 
    It shall be unlawful to place, store or keep any merchandise, building material or other thing within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant within the city limits or otherwise to obstruct passage to a fire hydrant within such distance. 
(Code 1973,  10-2) 
Sec. 5-2-4. - Crossing fire hose. 
    Whenever any hose of the fire department is laid upon any street, it shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to drive any vehicle over any such hose. 
(Code 1973,  10-3) 
Sec. 5-2-5. - False fire alarms. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to give or cause to be given any false fire alarm. 
(Code 1973,  10-4) 
Sec. 5-2-6. - Fire lines. 
    The fire chief shall establish fire lines where they are needed during any fire. It shall be unlawful for any person to pass through such fire lines without the permission of the fire chief. 
(Code 1973,  10-5) 
Sec. 5-2-7. - Overcrowding of structures. 
    No natural, charitable, governmental or business person or entity occupying, using, possessing, leasing or owning a structure, may permit overcrowding or admittance of anyone beyond the approved occupancy load of such structure. The fire official or his duly appointed representative, upon finding an overcrowded condition, or obstruction in aisles, passageways or other means of egress, or upon finding any condition which constitutes a hazard to life and safety, shall cause the occupancy, use, performance, presentation, spectacle or entertainment to be stopped until such condition or obstruction is corrected. 
(Ord. of 3-23-04) 
Sec. 5-2-8. - Appeal from decision of inspector to building code board of appeals. 
    An appeal from the decision of the fire inspector shall be heard and decided by the building code board of appeals as provided by section 11-1-11 of this Code. 
(Ord. of 5-27-86) 
Sec. 5-2-9. - Fees for hazardous materials response. 
    Whenever the fire department responds to any incident involving hazardous materials, as defined by  18.2-278.1 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended, the fire department shall, at the conclusion of the incident, present a statement to the person(s) or company(s) who was responsible for the spill or release of hazardous material to include all costs or charges for the emergency services supplied by the fire department. All billing will be handled by the fire chief. 
(Ord. of 5-10-88) 
Sec. 5-2-10. - Permit required for the handling of explosives and blasting agents. 
    Every person, firm, partnership or corporation who manufactures, uses, possesses, stores or sells any explosive or blasting agent, as defined in the statewide fire prevention code, shall be required to make application and obtain a permit from the city fire department. No permit issued shall be transferable to any other person, firm, partnership or corporation. 
(Ord. of 2-27-90; Ord. of 3-23-04) 
Sec. 5-2-11. - Requirements for permit for the handling of explosives and blasting agents. 
    Every person, firm, partnership or corporation who applies for a permit as set forth in section 5-20-10 shall comply with the following requirements: 
(a)  Shall furnish to the city fire department a valid certificate of insurance in an amount of not less than that established in the statewide fire prevention code. 
(b)  Shall not discharge explosives or blasting agents nor directly supervise the discharge of same on-site unless, the person or agent is certified in accordance with the Virginia certification standards for blasters. 
(Ord. of 2-27-90; Ord. of 3-23-04) 
Sec. 5-2-12. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted Mar. 23, 2004, repealed  5-2-12 in its entirety. Former  5-2-12 pertained to fees for the issuance of a permit under  5-2-10 and derived from an ordinance adopted Feb. 27, 1990. 
Sec. 5-2-13. - Time limit on permits. 
    A permit for the storage, handling, manufacturing or selling of explosives and blasting agents shall expire one (1) year from the date of its issue. A permit for the discharge of explosives and blasting agents for a specific project shall be issued for a specified time period, but in no case for a period greater than one (1) year. A permit issued pursuant to this section shall become invalid if the authorized activity is not commenced within six (6) months of the issuance of the permit, or if the authorized activity is abandoned or suspended for a period of six (6) months. 
(Ord. of 2-27-90; Ord. of 3-23-04) 
Sec. 5-2-14. - Penalty for violation of title 5, chapter 2. 
    Any person, business entity, firm, partnership or corporation, or individual responsible for the actions of such business entity, firm, partnership or corporation, who or which violates or fails to comply with the provisions of the statewide fire prevention code or this title 5, chapter 2, shall be guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor, and punishable as provided by state law. Each separate incident may be charged and punished as a separate offense. 
(Ord. of 2-27-90; Ord. of 3-23-04; Ord. of 4-14-15 ) 
Sec. 5-2-15. - Access. 
(a)  Emergency vehicle access. Emergency vehicle access shall be provided and maintained to all buildings undergoing construction, alteration or demolition. Emergency vehicle access roadways shall be of an approved surface material capable of providing vehicle access and support at all times. Emergency vehicle access roadways shall be a minimum of twenty (20) feet in unobstructed width. The access roadway shall provide a minimum turning radius capable of accommodating the largest fire apparatus of the city and a minimum vertical clearance of thirteen feet, six inches (13'6?). Upon determination that the physical conditions of the construction site will not allow compliance with the minimum access requirements, the building or fire inspector shall obtain adequate emergency vehicle access based on these physical limitations. 
(b)  Temporary roadways. Where approved by the code official, temporary emergency vehicle access roadways of such surface, width, turning radii and vehicle clearance which will permit access by emergency vehicles shall be allowed until permanent roadways are constructed. 
(c)  Firefighting access. Where required by the code official, temporary access to a building for the purpose of firefighting shall be provided. Construction materials shall not block any temporary firefighting access required by the code official or access to fire hydrants and fire department connections. 
(d)  Right to deny inspections. If a building or fire inspector finds that proper emergency vehicle access is not available to the site, the inspector shall have the authority to deny any and all building, construction or fire inspections until the proper emergency vehicle access is provided. 
(Ord. of 10-13-92; Ord. of 3-23-04) 
Sec. 5-2-16. - Smoke detectors in certain buildings. 
    Smoke detectors shall be installed in the following structures and buildings located within the city: (i) any building containing one (1) or more dwelling units, (ii) any hotel or motel regularly used or offered for, or intended to be used to provide overnight sleeping accommodations for one (1) or more persons, and (iii) rooming houses regularly used, offered for, or intended to be used to provide overnight sleeping accommodations. Smoke detectors installed pursuant to this section shall be installed in conformance with the provisions of the Uniform Statewide Building Code. The smoke detector can be either battery operated or AC powered units. The owner of any unit which is rented or leased, at the beginning of each tenancy or at least annually thereafter, shall furnish the tenant with a certificate that all required smoke detectors are present, have been inspected, and are in good working order. Except for smoke detectors located in hallways, stairwells, and other public or common areas of multifamily buildings, interim testing, repair and maintenance of smoke detectors in rented or leased units shall be the responsibility of the tenant; however, the owner shall be obligated to service, repair, or replace any malfunctioning smoke detectors within five (5) days of receipt of written notice from the tenant that such smoke detector is in need of service, repair, or replacement. 
(Ord. of 9-8-09(1)) 
Sec. 5-2-17. - Security gates. 
    The installation of security gates across a fire apparatus access road, as defined by the Virginia Statewide Fire Prevention Code, shall be approved by the fire chief. Where security gates are installed, they shall have an approved means of emergency operation. The security gates and the emergency operation shall be maintained operational at all times. Electric gate operators, where provided, shall be listed in accordance with UL 325. Gates intended for automatic operation shall be designed, constructed and installed to comply with the requirements of ASTM F 22UU. 
(Ord. of 1-28-14) 
Sec. 5-2-18. - Purpose. 
    The city council hereby finds that the use of combustible landscape cover material abutting or in very close proximity to buildings constructed with combustible siding is a fire hazard and constitutes a hazard to safety of such building and, more importantly, to the occupants of and visitors to such building. The regulation of the placement of combustible landscape cover material near combustible buildings is necessary to the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city and is authorized pursuant to Virginia Code Sections 15.2-1102 and 27-97, and Sections 101.5 and 110.1 of the Virginia Statewide Fire Prevention Code, which has been duly adopted by the city by section 5-2-1 of the Code of the City of Harrisonburg. 
( Ord. of 4-14-15 ; Ord. of 5-10-16(1)) 
Sec. 5-2-19. - Use of combustible landscape cover material. 
    Combustible landscape cover material shall not be placed within eighteen (18) inches of buildings with combustible siding, including, but not limited to, vinyl siding, wood siding, or Masonite. This ordinance shall apply to Occupancy Classifications A, B, E, F, H, I, M, R-1, R-2, R-4, as defined by the 2012 Virginia Construction Code, and to detached single family R-3 and R-5 residential structures being utilized as a child care facility or adult care facility. This ordinance shall not apply to any building which has a non-combustible foundation which rises at least six (6) feet above the mulch. 
( Ord. of 4-14-15 ; Ord. of 5-10-16(1)) 
Sec. 5-2-20. - Effective date. 
    This ordinance shall become effective upon passage by the Harrisonburg City Council. Combustible landscape cover material beds in existence on the effective date of this ordinance, will not require the removal of any combustible landscape cover material, however, no new combustible landscape cover material may be added within eighteen (18) inches of building as outlined in section 5-2-19. 
( Ord. of 4-14-15 ; Ord. of 5-10-16(1)) 
ARTICLE B. - OPEN BURNING REGULATIONS 

Sec. 5-2-21. - Title. 
    This article shall be known as the "City of Harrisonburg Ordinance for the Regulation of Open Burning." 
(Ord. of 8-27-96) 
Sec. 5-2-22. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to protect public health, safety, and welfare by regulating open burning within the city to achieve and maintain, to the greatest extent practicable, a level of air quality that will provide comfort and convenience while promoting economic and social development. This article is intended to supplement the applicable regulations promulgated by the State Air Pollution Control Board and other applicable regulations and laws. 
(Ord. of 8-27-96) 
Sec. 5-2-23. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article and subsequent amendments or any orders issued by the city, the words or phrases shall have the meaning given them in this section. 
    Automobile graveyard: Any lot or place which is exposed to the weather and upon which more than five (5) motor vehicles of any kind, incapable of being operated, and which it would not be economically practical to make operative, are placed, located or found. 
    Clean-burning waste: Waste which does not produce dense smoke when burned and is not prohibited to be burned under this chapter. 
    Construction waste: Solid waste which is produced or generated during construction of structures. Construction waste consists of lumber, wire, sheetrock, broken brick, shingles, glass, pipes, concrete, and metal and plastics if the metal and plastics are a part of the materials of construction or empty containers for such materials. Paints, coatings, solvents, asbestos, any liquid, compressed gases or semi-liquids, and garbage are not construction wastes and the disposal of such materials must be in accordance with the regulations of the Virginia Waste Management Board. 
    Debris waste: Stumps, wood, brush, and leaves from land clearing operations. 
    Demolition waste: That solid waste which is produced by the destruction of structures and their foundations and includes the same materials as construction waste. 
    Garbage: Rotting animal and vegetable matter accumulated by a household in the course of ordinary day to day living. 
    Hazardous waste: Refuse or combination of refuse which because of its quantity, concentration or physical, chemical or infectious characteristics may: 
(1)  Cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating illness; or 
(2)  Pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, disposed, or otherwise managed. 
    Household refuse: Waste material and trash normally accumulated by a household in the course of ordinary day to day living. 
    Industrial waste: All waste generated on the premises of manufacturing and industrial operations such as, but not limited to, those carried on in factories, processing plants, refineries, slaughter houses, and steel mills. 
    Junkyard: An establishment or place of business which is maintained, operated or used for storing, keeping, buying or selling junk, or for the maintenance or operation of an automobile graveyard, and the term shall include garbage dumps and sanitary fills. 
    Landfill: A sanitary landfill, an industrial landfill, or a construction/demolition/debris landfill. See Solid Waste Management Regulations (VR 672-20-10) for further definitions of these terms. 
    Local landfill: Any landfill located within the jurisdiction of the city. 
    Open burning: The burning of any matter in such a manner that the products resulting from combustion are emitted directly into the atmosphere without passing through a stack, duct or chimney. 
    Open pit incinerator: A device used to burn waste for the primary purpose of reducing the volume by removing combustible matter. Such devices function by directing a curtain of air at an angle across the top of a trench or similarly enclosed space, thus reducing the amount of combustion by-products emitted into the atmosphere. The term also includes trench burners, air curtain destructors and over draft incinerators. 
    Refuse: Trash, rubbish, garbage and other forms of solid or liquid waste, including, but not limited to, wastes resulting from residential, agricultural, commercial, industrial, institutional, trade, construction, land clearing, forest management and emergency operations. 
    Salvage operation: Any operation consisting of a business, trade or industry participating in salvaging or reclaiming any product or material, such as, but not limited to, reprocessing of used motor oils, metals, chemicals, shipping containers or drums, and specifically including automobile graveyards and junkyards. 
    Sanitary landfill: An engineered land burial facility for the disposal of household waste which is so located, designed, constructed and operated to contain and isolate the waste so that it does not pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment. A sanitary landfill also may receive other types of solid wastes, such as commercial solid waste, nonhazardous sludge, hazardous waste from conditionally exempt small quantity generators, and nonhazardous industrial solid waste. See Solid Waste Management Regulations (VR 672-20-10) for further definitions of these terms. 
    Smoke: Small gas-borne particulate matter consisting mostly, but not exclusively, of carbon, ash or other material in concentrations sufficient to form a visible plume. 
    Special incineration device: A pit incinerator, conical or tepee burner, or any other device specifically designed to provide good combustion performance. 
(Ord. of 8-27-96) 
Sec. 5-2-24. - Prohibitions on open burning. 
(a)  No owner or other person shall cause or permit open burning or the use of a special incineration device for disposal of refuse except as provided in this article. 
(b)  No owner or other person shall cause or permit open burning or the use of a special incineration device for disposal of rubber tires, asphaltic materials, crankcase oil, impregnated wood or other rubber or petroleum based materials except when conducting bona fide fire fighting instruction at fire fighting training schools having permanent facilities. 
(c)  No owner or other person shall cause or permit open burning or the use of a special incineration device for disposal of hazardous waste or containers for such materials. 
(d)  No owner or other person shall cause or permit open burning or the use of a special incineration device for the purpose of a salvage operation or for the disposal of commercial/industrial waste. 
(e)  Open burning or the use of special incineration devices permitted under the provisions of this article does not exempt or excuse any owner or other person from the consequences, liability, damages or injuries which may result from such conduct; nor does it excuse or exempt any owner or other person from complying with other applicable laws, ordinances, regulations and orders of the governmental entities having jurisdiction, even though the open burning is conducted in compliance with this article. In this regard special attention should be directed to section 10.1-1142 of the Forest Fire Law of Virginia, the regulations of the Virginia Waste Management Board, and the State Air Pollution Control Board's "Regulations for the Control and Abatement of Air Pollution." 
(f)  Upon declaration of an alert, warning or emergency stage of an air pollution episode as described in Part VII of the "Regulations for the Control and Abatement" of Air Pollution or when deemed advisable by the State Air Pollution Control Board to prevent a hazard to, or an unreasonable burden upon, public health or welfare, no owner or other person shall cause or permit open burning or use of a special incineration device; and any in process burning or use of a special incineration device shall be immediately terminated in the designated air quality control region. 
(Ord. of 8-27-96) 
Sec. 5-2-25. - Exemptions. 
    The following activities are exempted to the extent covered by the State Air Pollution Control Board's "Regulations for the Control and Abatement of Air Pollution:" 
(a)  Open burning for training and instruction of government and public fire fighters under the supervision of the designated official and industrial in-house firefighting personnel; 
(b)  Open burning for camp fires or other fires that are used solely for recreational purposes, for ceremonial occasions, for outdoor noncommercial preparation of food, and for warming of outdoor workers; 
(c)  Open burning for the destruction of any combustible liquid or gaseous material by burning in a flare of flare stack; 
(d)  Open burning for forest management and agriculture practices approved by the State Air Pollution Control Board; and 
(e)  Open burning for the destruction of classified military documents. 
(Ord. of 8-27-96) 
Sec. 5-2-26. - Permissible open burning. 
(a)  Open burning is permitted for the disposal of leaves and tree, yard and garden trimmings located on the premises of private property, provided that the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The burning takes place on the premises of the private property; 
(2)  The location of the burning is not less than three hundred (300) feet from any occupied building unless the occupants have given prior permission, other than a building located on the property on which the burning is conducted; and 
(3)  No regularly scheduled public or private collection service for such trimmings is available at the adjacent street or public road. 
(b)  Open burning is permitted for the disposal of household refuse by homeowners or tenants, provided that the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The burning takes place on the premises of the dwelling; 
(2)  Animal carcasses or animal wastes are not burned; 
(3)  Garbage is not burned; 
(4)  The location of the burning is not less than three hundred (300) feet from any occupied building unless the occupants have given prior permission, other than a building located on the property on which the burning is conducted; and 
(5)  No regularly scheduled public or private collection service for such refuse is available at the adjacent street or public road. 
(c)  Open burning is permitted for disposal of debris waste resulting from property maintenance, from development or modification of roads and highways, parking areas, railroad tracks, pipelines, power and communication lines, buildings or building areas, sanitary landfills, or from any other clearing operations which may be approved by the fire chief, provided the following conditions are met: 
(1)  All reasonable effort shall be made to minimize the amount of material burned, with the number and size of debris piles approved by the fire chief; 
(2)  The material to be burned shall consist of brush, stumps and similar debris waste and shall not include demolition material; 
(3)  The burning shall be at least five hundred (500) feet from any occupied building unless the occupants have given prior permission, other than a building located on the property on which the burning is conducted; 
(4)  The burning shall be conducted at the greatest distance practicable from highways and air fields; 
(5)  The burning shall be attended at all times and conducted to ensure the best possible combustion with a minimum of smoke being produced; 
(6)  The burning shall not be allowed to smolder beyond the minimum period of time necessary for the destruction of the materials; and 
(7)  The burning shall be conducted only when the prevailing winds are away from any city, town or built-up area. 
(d)  Open burning is permitted for disposal of debris on the site of local landfills provided that the burning does not take place on land that has been filled and covered so as to present an underground fire hazard due to the presence of methane gas provided that the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The burning shall take place on the premises of a local sanitary landfill which meets the provisions of the regulations of the Virginia Waste Management Board; 
(2)  The burning shall be attended at all times; 
(3)  The material to be burned shall consist only of brush, tree trimmings, yard and garden trimmings, clean burning construction waste, clean burning debris waste or clean burning demolition waste; 
(4)  All reasonable effort shall be made to minimize the amount of material that is burned; and 
(5)  No materials may be burned in violation of the regulations of the Virginia Waste Management Board or the State Air Pollution Control Board. The exact site of the burning on a local landfill shall be established in coordination with the regional director and fire chief; no other site shall be used without the approval of these officials. The fire chief shall be notified of the days during which the burning will occur. 
(Ord. of 8-27-96) 
Sec. 5-2-27. - Permits. 
(a)  When open burning of debris waste (section 5-2-26(c)) or open burning of debris on the site of a local landfill (section 5-2-26(d)) is to occur within the city, the person responsible for the burning shall obtain a permit from the fire chief prior to the burning. Such a permit may be granted only after confirmation by the fire chief that the burning can and will comply with the provisions of this chapter and any other conditions which are deemed necessary to ensure that the burning will not endanger the public health and welfare or to ensure compliance with any applicable provisions of the State Air Pollution Control Board's Regulations for the Control and Abatement of Air Pollution. The permit may be issued for each occasion of burning or for a specific period of time deemed appropriate by the fire chief. 
(b)  Prior to the initial installation (or reinstallation, in cases of relocation) and operation of special incineration devices, the person responsible for the burning shall obtain a permit from the fire chief, such permits to be granted only after confirmation by the fire chief that the burning can and will comply with the applicable provisions in "Regulations for the Control and Abatement of Air Pollution" and that any conditions are met which are deemed necessary by the fire chief to ensure that the operation of the devices will not endanger the public health and welfare. Permits granted for the use of special incineration devices shall at a minimum contain the following conditions: 
(1)  All reasonable effort shall be made to minimize the amount of material that is burned. Such efforts shall include, but are not limited to, the removal of pulpwood, sawlogs and firewood. 
(2)  The material to be burned shall consist of brush, stumps and similar debris waste shall not include demolition material. 
(3)  The burning shall be at least three hundred (300) feet from any occupied building unless the occupants have given prior permission, other than a building located on the property on which the burning is conducted; burning shall be conducted at the greatest distance practicable from highways and air fields. If the fire chief determines that it is necessary to protect public health and welfare, he may direct that any of the above-cited distances be increased. 
(4)  The burning shall be attended at all times and conducted to ensure the best possible combustion with a minimum of smoke being produced. Under no circumstances should the burning be allowed to smolder beyond the minimum period of time necessary for the destruction of the materials. 
(5)  The burning shall be conducted only when the prevailing winds are away from any city, town or built-up area. 
(6)  The use of special incineration devices shall be allowed only for the disposal of debris waste, clean-burning construction waste and clean-burning demolition waste. 
(7)  Permits issued under this subsection shall be limited to a specific period of time deemed appropriate by the fire chief. 
(c)  An application for a permit under this section shall be accompanied by a processing fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. of 8-27-96) 
Secs. 5-2-28-5-2-30. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted Mar. 23, 2004, repealed  5-2-28 in its entirety. Former  5-2-28 pertained to penalties for violation and derived from an ordinance adopted Aug. 27, 1996. 
ARTICLE C. - FIRE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 5-2-31. - Composition. 
(a)  The fire department of the city shall consist of the chief of fire, a deputy chief of fire and such number of captains, lieutenants, firefighters, dispatchers or other employees by whatever rank they may be designated as the council, on the recommendations of the city manager, may prescribe. 
(b)  In addition, the fire department of the city shall be composed of such number of fire stations and paid and volunteer fire companies as may be deemed necessary by the fire chief and approved by the city manager. 
(Ord. of 5-10-88) 
Sec. 5-2-32. - Composition and organization of volunteer companies. 
    Each of the volunteer fire companies shall be composed of not less than twenty (20) members. The organization of the volunteer fire companies shall conform to the requirements of  27-6 through 27-33 and  27-41 through 27-50, Code of Virginia. 
(Code 1973,  10-14) 
Sec. 5-2-33. - "Volunteer fireman" defined. 
    For purposes of this article, the term "volunteer fireman" shall include only members of an organized firefighting company which has in its possession and operates firefighting equipment, whose members are at least sixteen (16) years of age, serve without pay, and whose names have been duly certified by the secretary of the company as active members thereof to the clerk of the circuit court of the county for recordation in his office, as required by  27-42, Code of Virginia, as amended. 
(Code 1973,  10-15; Ord. of 5-10-88) 
Sec. 5-2-34. - Rules, regulations and bylaws of volunteer companies. 
    The volunteer fire companies shall have the right and it shall be their duty to adopt and enforce such rules, regulations and bylaws pertaining to their organization, their government, membership, officers and activities and work as they deem proper and as will best promote efficiency, promptness and economy in the accomplishment of the work and purpose in the fire department. The general purpose of such rules, regulations and bylaws shall be to avoid and minimize injuries and losses to persons and property arising from fire, lightning or similar damages. Such rules, regulations and bylaws shall not be inconsistent with the laws of the state or the ordinances of the city, the rules and regulations of the Harrisonburg Fire Department, or the standard operating procedures of the Harrisonburg Fire Department. 
Sec. 5-2-35. - Fire chief-Appointment; duties; term of office. 
(a)  The fire chief shall be appointed by the city manager and shall serve at the pleasure and direction of the city manager. 
(b)  The fire chief shall be responsible for all aspects of life safety as it relates to fires, entrapment and rescue situations. At the scene of any fire or life-threatening incident, the fire chief, or his designee, shall assume command and exercise control over the operation. 
(c)  The fire chief is hereby appointed to serve as the fire official as that term is used from time to time in the Code of Virginia (1950), as amended (the Code), as the fire marshal as set forth in Code Section 27-30 et seq., as the hazardous materials coordinator as set forth in Code Section 44-146.34 et seq., and as the coordinator of emergency management as set forth in Code Section 44-146.13 et seq.; and is authorized to and shall exercise all of the powers and carry out the duties enunciated therein. 
(d)  The fire chief is empowered to appoint one (1) or more assistant fire marshals, who, in the absence of the fire marshal, shall have the powers and perform the duties of the fire marshal. 
(Code 1973,  10-17; Ord. of 2-27-90; Ord. of 6-22-04; Ord. of 5-23-17(1)) 
Sec. 5-2-36. - Same-Devolution of powers and duties upon absence. 
    In the absence of the fire chief, the deputy fire chief shall perform the duties and possess the powers of the fire chief. In case of the deputy chief's absence also, the ranking city fire officer on duty for the day is in command. 
Sec. 5-2-37. - Same-Control over firemen; firemen to obey. 
(a)  The fire chief shall have full power and control over all members of the city department, regardless of whether they are volunteer firemen or firemen paid by the city. With respect to the paid members, such power and control shall exist at all times that they are on duty, whether fighting fires or at fire stations. With respect to the volunteer firemen, such power and control shall exist at all times that they are engaged in any act connected with their duties as volunteer firemen or in a city fire station. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of all members of the fire department, both paid and volunteer, to obey all orders and directions given by the fire chief respecting their actions and conduct connected in any way with their service and duties as firemen. If any paid fireman shall disobey or disregard any order or direction given by the fire chief, proper disciplinary action shall be taken by the chief. If any volunteer fireman shall disobey or disregard any order or direction given by the fire chief, he shall be suspended by the fire chief for such period as he deems proper. In case of such suspension, the fire chief shall promptly thereafter report in writing the fact and circumstances thereof to the president of the company of which the offending person is a member, for such further action thereon as the company may desire to take. 
Sec. 5-2-38. - Rescue squad official recognition. 
    Harrisonburg Rescue Squad, Inc., is hereby recognized as an integral part of the official safety program of the city for the purposes of saving lives, administering first aid and teaching safety. 
(Code of 1973,  10-21; Ord. of 2-27-79) 
Sec. 5-2-39. - Granting franchise permits; authorizing charges for emergency medical services vehicles. 
(a)  In order to assure the provision of adequate and continuing emergency services and to preserve, protect and promote the public health, safety and general welfare, the city council finds, after a public hearing held on August 25, 2009, the following: 
(1)  It shall be unlawful to operate emergency medical services vehicles or any class thereof established by the city council without having been granted a franchise or permit to do so; 
(2)  The city shall grant franchises or permits to agencies based within or outside the city; provided, however, any agency in operation in the city on June 28, 1968, that continues to operate as such, up to and including the effective date of this section, and that submits to the city council satisfactory evidence of such continuing operation, shall be granted a franchise or permit by the city council to serve the city in which the agency has continuously operated if all other requirements of this section are met; 
(3)  The city shall have the authority to limit the number of emergency medical services vehicles to be operated within the city and by any agency; 
(4)  The city shall have the authority to determine and prescribe areas of franchised or permitted service within the city; 
(5)  The city shall have the authority to fix and change from time to time reasonable charges for franchised or permitted services; 
(6)  The city shall have the authority to set minimum limits of liability insurance coverage for emergency medical services vehicles; 
(7)  The city shall have the authority to contract with franchised or permitted agencies for transportation to be rendered upon call of a city agency or department and for transportation of bona fide indigents or persons certified by the local board of social services to be public assistance or social services recipients; and 
(8)  The city shall have the authority to establish other necessary regulations consistent with statutes and regulations of the city council relating to operation of emergency medical services vehicles. 
(b)  In addition to the powers set forth above, the city council is authorized to provide, or cause to be provided, services of emergency medical services vehicles; to own, operate and maintain emergency medical services vehicles, to make reasonable charges for use of emergency medical services vehicles, including charging insurers for ambulance services as authorized by  38.2-3407.9 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended, and to contract with any agency for the services of its emergency medical services vehicles. 
(c)  Any emergency medical services vehicles operated by the city shall be subject to the provisions as set forth in the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended, and by the Virginia Department of Health. 
(Ord. of 9-8-09(3)) 
Sec. 5-2-40. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. of 11-24-09(3), repealed  5-2-40, which pertained to charges for emergency medical services vehicles and derived from Ord. of 9-8-09(3). 
Sec. 5-2-41. - Powers and duties of fire marshal; assistants. 
(a)  In addition to any other duties prescribed by law, the fire marshal and his assistants shall have the authority to arrest, to procure and serve warrants of arrest, and to issue summons in the manner authorized by general law for violation of fire prevention and fire safety laws and related ordinances, in accordance with the provisions of  27-34.2 of the Code of Virginia, as amended. 
(b)  The fire marshal and his assistants shall have the same police powers as a sheriff, police officer or law enforcement officer, and shall have responsibility for the investigation and prosecution of offenses involving hazardous materials, fires, fire bombings, bombings, attempts or threats to commit such offenses, false alarms relating to such offenses, possession and manufacture of explosive devices, substances and fire bombs, in accordance with the provisions of  27-34.2:1 of the Code of Virginia, as amended. 
(c)  The fire marshal shall have the right to enter upon any property from which a release of any hazardous material, hazardous waste or regulated substance, as defined in  10.1-1400 or  62.1-44.34:8 of the Code of Virginia, as amended, has occurred or is reasonably suspected to have occurred, and which has entered into the ground water, surface water or soils of the city, accordance with the provisions of  27-37.1 of the Code of Virginia, as amended. 
(Ord. of 5-28-17) 
CHAPTER 3. - OFFICE OF EMERGENCY SERVICES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Emergency services and disaster law, Code of Va., Title 44, Ch. 3.2. 

Sec. 5-3-1. - Creation of office. 
    The office of emergency services of the city is hereby created. This office shall be responsible for local disaster preparedness and coordination of response with the consent of council as provided by law. 
Sec. 5-3-2. - Coordination of office. 
    Pursuant to  44-146.19 of the Code of Virginia (1950), as amended, the functions and duties of the office of emergency management shall be carried out by the city manager, serving as the director of emergency management, the deputy city manager, serving as the deputy director of emergency management, and by the fire chief who, pursuant to chapter 2 of this title, shall serve as the coordinator of emergency management. The city manager may appoint a deputy coordinator, as he deems appropriate. City officials serving in the office of emergency management shall carry out their duties in consultation with the mayor or his representative from city council, as the circumstances permit. 
(Ord. of 3-23-04; Ord. of 10-27-15(2) ) 
CHAPTER 4. - HERBICIDES 

Sec. 5-4-1. - Authority of council. 
    The authority vested in the council by this chapter may be delegated to such employees as the city manager may designate. Said employees shall have the right to make reasonable inspections at reasonable hours on any premises or property in the city to enforce this chapter. 
(Ord. of 3-22-83) 
Sec. 5-4-2. - High volatile phenoxy herbicides. 
    High volatile phenoxy herbicides shall not be used in the city between April 1 and December 1 of any calendar year. 
(Ord. of 3-22-83) 
Sec. 5-4-3. - Low volatile phenoxy herbicides. 
    Low volatile phenoxy herbicides shall not be used in the city between April 15 and June 1 of any calendar year. 
(Ord. of 3-22-83) 
Sec. 5-4-4. - Amine herbicide formulations. 
    Amine herbicide formulations may be used in the city throughout the calendar year. 
(Ord. of 3-22-83) 
Sec. 5-4-5. - Application of permitted phenoxy herbicides. 
    The application of permitted phenoxy herbicides, low volatile phenoxy herbicides and amine formulated and oil soluble amine phenoxy herbicides shall be done under the following conditions: 
(1)  When the ground wind speed does not exceed ten (10) miles per hour at time of application. 
(2)  The pressure in the sprayer at the time of application shall not exceed thirty (30) pounds per square inch at the nozzle. 
(3)  No phenoxy herbicides shall be applied with the use of fixed wing aircraft. 
(Ord. of 3-22-83) 
CHAPTER 5. - E-911 TAX 

Sec. 5-5-1. - E-911 tax. 
    The E-911 tax which was adopted on March 24, 1992, in the original amount of sixty cents ($0.60) per month per access line, and was increased to one dollar and forty-four cents ($1.44) per month per access line on July 28, 1998, is hereby increased to three dollars ($3.00) per month per access line effective April 1, 2005. 
(Ord. of 7-28-98; Ord. of 2-8-05) 
CHAPTER 6. - AUXILIARY POLICE FORCE (NEW 7/1/2001) 
ARTICLE A. - TITLE; PURPOSE; APPLICABILITY 

Sec. 5-6-1. - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the City of Harrisonburg Auxiliary Police Force Ordinance. 
(Ord. of 4-24-01(2)) 
Cross reference- For authority to establish, see Code of Va., 1950 as amended,  15.1-159.2 et seq. 
Sec. 5-6-2. - Applicability. 
    This chapter shall apply to the incorporated territory of the city and city-owned property outside the incorporated territory. 
(Ord. of 4-24-01(2)) 
Sec. 5-6-3. - Purpose. 
    This chapter is adopted for the further preservation of the public peace, safety, and good order of the city. 
(Ord. of 4-24-01(2)) 
ARTICLE B. - DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 5-6-4. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the words used herein are defined as follows: 
    Auxiliary police force. A supplemental police contingent (unit) comprised of citizen volunteers selectively used to conduct a variety of operational support and administrative assignments. 
ARTICLE C. - APPOINTMENT; AUTHORITY AND FUNCTION 

Sec. 5-6-5. - Appointment of auxiliary members. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority to appoint as auxiliary police officers as many persons of good character as he shall deem necessary, not to exceed twenty-five (25), and their appointment shall be revocable at any time by the chief of police. 
(Ord. of 4-24-01(2)) 
Sec. 5-6-6. - Authority to prescribe uniform, equipment, organization and regulations. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority to prescribe the uniform, equipment, organization and such rules and regulations as he shall deem necessary for the operation of the auxiliary police force. 
(Ord. of 4-24-01(2)) 
Sec. 5-6-7. - When auxiliary police personnel may be called into service. 
    The chief of police or the city manager may call into service such auxiliary police officers as may be deemed necessary: 
(1)  In time of public emergency; 
(2)  At such times as there are insufficient number of regular police officers to preserve the peace, safety, and good order of the community; and 
(3)  At any time for the purpose of training such auxiliary police officers. 
(Ord. of 4-24-01(2)) 
Sec. 5-6-8. - Powers, immunities of auxiliary police personnel. 
    The members of the auxiliary police force, when called into service, shall have all the powers and immunities of constables at common law, subject to such limitations on powers as may from time to time be prescribed in general orders for such auxiliary police force. 
(Ord. of 4-24-01(2)) 
Sec. 5-6-9. - Jurisdictional limitations of auxiliary personnel. 
    The members of the auxiliary police force shall not be required to act beyond the limits of the jurisdiction of the city, except when called upon to protect any public property belonging to the city which may be located beyond its boundaries. 
(Ord. of 4-24-01(2)) 
Sec. 5-6-10. - Compensation and civil service status of auxiliary personnel. 
    The members of the auxiliary police force shall serve as such without compensation and shall not be subject to the provisions of any law, ordinance, regulation, policy or procedure providing rights or benefits of any nature to the regular police force or employees of the city; nor shall the members be entitled to any of the benefits of regular police officers as provided by the laws of the commonwealth or ordinances, resolutions and policies of the city. 
(Ord. of 4-24-01(2)) 
Sec. 5-6-11. - Auxiliary personnel to wear uniforms and equipment. 
    The members of the auxiliary police force shall wear the uniform and equipment prescribed by the chief of police at all times while serving as auxiliary police officers. 
(Ord. of 4-24-01(2)) 
Sec. 5-6-12. - Eligibility requirements; application for membership. 
    Any citizen of the United States who is a resident, business owner or employed in the City of Harrisonburg, Virginia, and who is between the ages of twenty-one (21) and seventy-five (75) shall be eligible to make application to become a member of the auxiliary police force. Applicants shall apply and will be selected in the form and manner prescribed by the chief of police. 
(Ord. of 4-24-01(2); Ord. of 8-28-01) 
Sec. 5-6-13. - Auxiliary personnel and conflicts of interest. 
    Applicants for the auxiliary police force must not be employed in positions presenting a potential conflict of interest. They include police officers, security guards, military police officers, civilians in law enforcement positions, and firefighters. 
(Ord. of 4-24-01(2)) 
CHAPTER 7. - MALFUNCTIONING ALARM SYSTEMS AND FALSE ALARMS 

Sec. 5-7-1. - Purpose. 
    The city council hereby finds that malfunctioning alarm systems, and the false alarms associated with them, constitute a hazard to public safety personnel and the public in general. The regulation of alarm systems and false alarms is necessary to promote the health, safety, and welfare of city citizens. False alerts of intrusions or robberies increase the city's public safety costs, divert public safety resources from other critical areas of work and burden the Harrisonburg-Rockingham Emergency Communications Center. In order to preserve the integrity and efficiency of the city's police and fire and rescue emergency services, those who utilize automatic alarm systems must be required to maintain those systems in good working order, to familiarize themselves with the proper operation of those systems, and to promptly repair any defects which may cause those systems to trigger false alarms. 
(Ord. of 6-8-14, eff. 9-1-14) 
Sec. 5-7-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm administrator means a person or persons designated by the city to administer, control and review false alarm reduction efforts and administers the provisions of this chapter. 
    Alarm company means a person or entity subject to the licensing requirements for a company engaged in selling, leasing, installing, servicing or monitoring alarm systems; this person or entity shall be licensed in compliance with city and commonwealth laws. 
    Alarm permit means a permit issued by the city allowing the operation of an alarm system within the city. 
    Alarm signal means a detectable signal; audible or visual, generated by an alarm system, to which law enforcement is requested to respond. 
    Alarm system means any single device or assembly of equipment designed to signal the occurrence or presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to which a police or fire and rescue response is expected, but does not include motor vehicle or boat alarms,, domestic violence alarms, or alarms designed to elicit a medical response other than fire and rescue services. 
    Alarm user means any person, corporation, partnership, proprietorship or any other entity owning, leasing or operating an alarm system, or on whose premises an alarm system is maintained for the protection of such premises. An "alarm user" shall not include the United States, the Commonwealth of Virginia, or their respective agencies or political subdivisions. 
    Alarm user awareness class means a class conducted for the purpose of educating alarm users about the responsible use, operation, and maintenance of alarm systems and the problems created by false alarms. 
    Automatic dial protection device means an automatic dialing device or an automatic telephone dialing alarm system and shall include any system which, upon being activated, automatically initiates to the ECC a recorded message or code signal indicating a need for law enforcement or fire and rescue response. 
    Cancellation means the process where response is terminated when the alarm company (designated by the alarm user) notifies the Harrisonburg Police Department, Harrisonburg Fire Department, or ECC after an alarm dispatch request, but prior to police or fire and rescue arriving at the scene, that there is not an existing situation at the alarm site requiring police or fire and rescue response. During any permit year, the first five (5) cancellations will not constitute a false alarm for the purpose civil penalty, and no penalty will be assessed. Each cancellation in excess of five (5) per permit year by an alarm user shall constitute a false alarm. 
    City means the City of Harrisonburg, Virginia or its agent. 
    ECC means the Harrisonburg-Rockingham Emergency Communications Center. 
    False alarm means an alarm that causes a police or fire and rescue response when there is no actual or threatened criminal activity, fire, or other emergency requiring an immediate police or fire and rescue response. False alarms shall include, but not be limited to: negligently or accidentally activated signals; signals which are the result of faulty, malfunctioning or improperly installed or maintained equipment; signals which are purposefully activated to summon a police or fire and rescue response in nonemergency situations; and alarms for which the actual cause is not determined. False alarms shall not include any alarms caused by failure of the equipment of the ECC, or any alarms determined by the responding police or fire and rescue officer to have been triggered by criminal activity, activity unauthorized by the alarms system user, or activity outside the control of the alarm system user. 
    Local alarm means an alarm system that emits a signal at an alarm site that is audible or visible from the exterior of a structure and is not monitored by a remote monitoring facility, whether installed by an alarm company or user. 
    Permit year means a twelve-month period beginning on the day and month on which an alarm permit is issued. 
    SIA Control Panel Standard CP-01 means the American National Standard Institute (ANSI) approved Security Industry Association (SIA) CP-01 Control Panel Standard, as may be updated from time to time, that details recommended design features for security system control panels and their associated arming and disarming devices to reduce false alarms. Control panels built and tested to this standard by a nationally recognized testing organization, will be marked to state: "Design evaluated in accordance with SIA CP-01 Control Panel Standard Features for False Alarm Reduction". 
    Verify means an attempt by the monitoring company, or its representative, to contact the alarm site and/or alarm user by telephone and/or other electronic means, whether or not actual contact with a person is made, to attempt to determine whether an alarm signal is valid before requesting law enforcement dispatch, in an attempt to avoid an unnecessary alarm dispatch request. For the purpose of this chapter, telephone verification shall require, as a minimum that a second call be made to a different number if the first attempt fails to reach an alarm user who can properly identify themselves to attempt to determine whether an alarm signal is valid before requesting law enforcement dispatch. Fire alarms shall not be verified before requesting fire and rescue dispatch. 
(Ord. of 6-8-14, eff. 9-1-14) 
Sec. 5-7-3. - Alarm registration. 
(1)  Registration required. No person shall use an alarm system without first registering such alarm system with the city. A fee shall not be required for the initial registration and annual renewals. Each alarm registration shall be assigned a unique registration number, and the user shall provide the registration number to the alarm company to facilitate police and fire and rescue dispatch. 
(2)  Registration form. Every alarm system shall be registered on a registration form provided by the city. An alarm user has the duty to obtain a registration form from the city. 
(3)  Transfer of possession. When the possession of the premises at which an alarm system is maintained is transferred, the person (user) obtaining possession of the property shall file a new registration form for an alarm permit within thirty (30) days of obtaining possession of the property. Alarm system registrations are not transferable. 
(4)  Reporting updated information. Whenever the information provided on the alarm registration changes, the alarm user shall provide correct information to the city within thirty (30) days of the change. In addition, each year after the registration of the alarm system, the alarm system user will receive from the city a form requesting updated information. The alarm system user shall complete and return this form to the city when any of the requested information has changed. Failure to comply will constitute a violation of this chapter and may result in a civil penalty. 
(5)  Multiple alarm systems. If an alarm user has one (1) or more alarm systems protecting two (2) or more separate structures having different addresses and/or tenants, separate registration shall be required for each structure and/or tenant. 
(Ord. of 6-8-14, eff. 9-1-14) 
Sec. 5-7-4. - Duties of the alarm user. 
(1)  Alarm system users shall: 
a.  Maintain their alarm systems in good working order. 
b.  Provide the alarm company the registration number. 
c.  Respond and cause a representative to arrive to the alarm system's location within thirty (30) minutes when notified by the ECC. 
d.  Not manually activate an alarm for any reason other than an occurrence of an event that the alarm system was intended to report, or for a scheduled fire drill or alarm testing. The alarm user shall notify the ECC prior to conducting a fire drill or alarm testing. 
e.  Obtain a new registration and pay any associated fees if there is a change in address or ownership of a business or residence. 
(Ord. of 6-8-14, eff. 9-1-14) 
Sec. 5-7-5. - Duties of the alarm company. 
(1)  Any person engaged in the alarm business in the city shall: 
a.  Obtain and maintain the required Commonwealth and city license(s). 
b.  Be able to provide name, address, and telephone number of the license holder or a designee, who can be called in an emergency, twenty-four (24) hours a day; and be able to respond to an alarm call, when notified, within two (2) hours. 
c.  Be able to provide the most current contact information for the alarm user. 
(2)  Ninety (90) days after enactment of this chapter the alarm installation companies shall, on all new and upgraded installations, use only alarm control panel(s) which meet SIA Control Panel Standard CP-01. 
(3)  Prior to activation of the alarm system, the alarm company must provide instructions explaining the proper operation of the alarm system to the alarm user. 
(4)  Provide written information of how to obtain service from the alarm company for the alarm system to the alarm user. 
(5)  An alarm company performing monitoring services shall: 
a.  In the event of an alarm requiring police response, attempt to verify, by calling the alarm site and/or alarm user by telephone, to determine whether an alarm signal is valid before requesting dispatch. Telephone verification shall require, as a minimum that a second call be made to a different number, if the first attempt fails to reach an alarm user who can properly identify themselves to attempt to determine whether an alarm signal is valid, except in the case of a panic or robbery-in-progress alarm, or in cases where a crime-in-progress has been verified by video and/or audible means. Fire alarms shall not be verified prior to requesting fire and rescue dispatch. 
b.  Provide alarm user registration number to the ECC to facilitate dispatch and/or cancellations.
